823 East Seventh Street, Saint Paul, MN 55106  651- 774-9010   www.energycents.org  
  
 
August 30, 2024  
 
 
 
Will Seuﬀert          VIA E -FILING   
Executive Secretary  
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission  
121 7th Place East, Suite 250  
St. Paul, MN 55101  
 Re:  In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
PUC Docket Number:  E015/PA -24-198 
 
Dear Mr. Seuﬀert:  
 
The Energy CENTS Coalition  (“ECC”) appreciates the opportunity to comment in  the above -
referenced matter.  ECC promotes aﬀordable energy service for low - and ﬁxed -income 
Minnesotans through regulatory proceedings, policy advocacy, and the administration of direct 
utility bill- payment and conservation assistance programs.  Through the years , we have worked 
extensively with Minnesota Power on the design of their aﬀordability programs.  We would like 
to begin by thanking Minnesota Power  for the commitments they  made in their  initial ﬁling , in 
which they state:   
 
Minnesota Power commits that it will not reduce the overall scope or resources 
dedicated to its aﬀordability programs, nor current processes for residential customer 
access to aﬀordability programs following the completion of the Acquisition.
1  
 
As detailed in our April 15, 2024  ﬁling in Docket 11- 409, commenting on the 2023 CARE Annual 
Report , Minnesota Power has made incredible strides in expanding access to and beneﬁts from 
the CARE program. Features such as allowing for self -attestation of income by program 
 
1 Petition at  4. 

 
 
823 East Seventh Street, Saint Paul, MN 55106  651- 774-9010   www.energycents.org  
 participants have made CARE a model for aﬀordability programs across the State.2 It goes without 
saying that, for  the acquisition to be in the public interest, it must hold low -income customers 
harmless by maintaining the beneﬁts it currently provides. For that reason, we are heartened by 
the Company’s commitments to preserving the CARE program.  
 Nonetheless, given the complexity of the acquisition, ECC anticipates that  the Commission will 
refer this matter to an Administrative Law Judge , and we intend to participate in that proceeding. 
ECC appreciates the work of the Citizens Utilities Board , the Oﬃce of the Attorney General , the 
Department of Commerce and the Large Power Intervenors to suggest questions for further 
development in a contested case
3, but we ﬁnd reasonable  the modiﬁcations that Minnesota 
Power  proposed in its reply comments.4 
 If you have any questions, I can be reached  at (651) 245 -1644 or via electronic mail at 
george@energycents.org.  
 
Thank you for your consideration.  
 
Sincerely,  
 
George Wm Shardlow  
 
George Shardlow  
Executive Director  
Energy CENTS Coalition  
 
  CC: Service list  
    
 
   
 
2 Energy CENTS Coalition Comments, In the Matter of Minnesota Power’s Petition for Approval of a Rider for 
Customer Aﬀordability of Residential Electricity (CARE), DOCKET NO. E -015/M -11-409, April 15, 2024.  
3 CUB Initial Comments  at 4.  
4 Minnesota Power Reply Comments at 13 . 
AFFIDAVIT OF SERVICE 
George Shardlow certifies that, on August 30, 2024, he submitted, by electronic filing, the 
Energy CENTS Coalition's Reply Comments In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power 
for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructur e Partners Docket No. E0lS/PA-24-198 to the individuals on the attached service 
list. 
George Shardlow 
Fredi Pierce 
Subscribed and sworn to me this 30th day of August, 2024.

In
the
Matter
of
the
Petition
of
Minnesota
Power
for
the
Acquisition
of
ALLETE
by 
Canada
Pension
Plan
Investment
Board
and
Global
Infrastructur e
Partners
PUC
Docket
No.
E-015/P A-24-198
LIUNA
Minnesota
and
North
Dakota
(“LIUNA”)
appreciates
the
opportunity
to
offer
reply 
comments
concerning
the
petition
filed
by
Minnesota
Power
concerning
the
planned
acquisition 
of
parent
company
ALLETE,
Inc.
by
Global
Infrastructure
Partners
(“GIP”)
and
the
Canada 
Pension
Plan
Investment
Board
(“CPP”).
Based
on
the
information
provided
to
date
by
ALLETE 
and
the
company’ s
proposed
new
owners,
we
believe
that
the
transaction
has
the
potential
to 
provide
significant
benefits
to
the
utility’ s
customers
and
the
state
as
a
whole
with
minimal
risks.
In
our
experience,
the
owners
of
publicly-traded
stocks
are
neither
more
civic-minded,
nor
less 
profit-driven,
than
investors
in
private
equity
or
similar
funds
managed
by
institutions
like
GIP 
and
CPP.
LIUNA
has
many
years
of
experience
with
GIP,
which
would
hold
a
controlling 
interest
in
ALLETE
when
the
transaction
closes.
A
number
of
pension
funds
affiliated
with 
LIUNA
have
made
investments
in
funds
managed
by
GIP,
and
we
have
worked
with
GIP
on
the 
adoption
and
enforcement
of
a
responsible
contractor
policy
that
protects
both
investors
and 
workers
from
risks
associated
with
contractors
that
operate
in
an
unethical
or
unsafe
manner 
across
GIP’ s
portfolio.
We
are
comfortable
that
GIP
is,
if
anything,
more
responsible
and
responsive
than
the
average 
fund
manager
holding
ALLETE’ s
publicly-traded
stock.
While
we
have
less
direct
experience 
working
with
CPP,
we
have
generally
found
that
public
pension
fund
investment
managers
like 
CPP
have
the
same
preference
for
stable,
well-managed,
long-term
investments
as
trustees
of 
LIUNA
funds.
We
recognize
that
concerns
have
been
raised
about
the
pending
acquisition
of
GIP 
by
investment
giant
BlackRock,
but
to
the
degree
that
BlackRock
is
a
leading
owner
of
nearly 
every
type
of
investment,
including
stocks,
bonds,
real
estate
and
private
equity ,
we
do
not
see 
their
ownership
of
GIP
causing
a
material
difference
in
GIP’ s
operation.
Most
importantly ,
however ,
we
are
confident
that
the
proposed
change
in
ownership
does
not 
jeopardize
interests
of
customers
or
the
public
at
large
because
Minnesota’ s
system
of
utility 
regulation
–
including
a
robust
legal
framework
and
active
oversight
by
regulators
–
prevents 
owners
from
using
utilities
to
reap
excess
profits
at
public
expense.
Investors,
including
public 
and
Taft-Hartley
pension
funds,
would
always
prefer
to
earn
larger
rather
than
smaller
returns 
whether
they
are
investing
in
private
equity
funds
or
utility
stocks.
But
the
usual
means
of 
boosting
profits
are
not
available
to
investors
in
a
well-regulated
utility ,
which
cannot
raise 
prices
without
regulatory
approvals,
or
underfund
operations
without
undercutting
their
own
rate 
cases
and
risking
the
wrath
of
regulators.
While
we
do
not
see
meaningful
risks
associated
with
the
proposed
change
in
ownership,
we 
anticipate
potential
benefits.
First,
ALLETE
is
currently
a
small
fish
in
a
very
large
energy 
infrastructure
pond.
As
the
nation
and
the
world
seek
to
transition
rapidly
to
clean
energy 
through
the
replacement
of
fossil
generation,
expansion
of
transmission
and
distribution,
and

scale-up
of
the
electric
system
to
meet
demands
from
electrification
national
and
global
supply 
chains
are
struggling
to
keep
up
with
demand
for
transformers,
solar
panels,
wind
turbines, 
electrolyzers,
and
other
key
components
of
a
clear
grid.
The
proposed
acquisition
has
the 
potential
to
put
additional
scale
and
leverage
at
the
disposal
of
Minnesota
Power
as
the
utility 
seeks
to
compete
for
timely
access
to
technology
at
a
reasonable
price.
Second,
we
believe
that
GIP
and
CPP
could
be
instrumental
in
helping
Minnesota
Power
and
its 
ratepayers
secure
the
thing
that
could
deliver
the
greatest
benefits
–
new
beneficial
load
from 
large
commercial
and
industrial
customers.
Minnesota
Power
is
already
a
leader
among
utilities 
nationwide
in
its
efforts
to
support
economic
development
efforts
that
create
jobs
and
economic 
activity
while
spreading
fixed
costs
among
a
larger
customer
base.
But
the
utility’ s
reach
is 
limited
by
its
small
size
and
geography .
The
most
significant
and
lowest-risk
opportunity
for
GIP 
and
CPP
to
increase
the
value
of
their
investment
in
Minnesota
Power
is
to
bring
economic 
development
to
Northeast
Minnesota
by
helping
to
recruit
businesses
seeking
reliable
clean 
power
that
can
bring
beneficial
load.
We
recognize
that
other
parties
lack
our
confidence
that
this
transaction
will
be 
neutral-to-beneficial
for
Minnesota
Power
customers
and
communities,
and
we
are
open
to 
participating
in
a
contested
case
as
necessary
as
long
as
the
proceeding
can
be
accomplished 
within
a
reasonable
timeline
that
does
not
jeopardize
the
opportunity
presented
by
the
proposed 
acquisition.
We
do
not
see
any
evidence
in
the
record
or
other
indications
that
lengthy 
proceedings
are
needed
to
answer
questions
that
are
not
novel
about
a
transaction
that
will
not 
fundamentally
change
the
relationship
between
the
regulated
utility
in
question
and
its 
regulators,
customers
or
other
stakeholders.
Thank
you
for
your
consideration.
Dated:
August
28,
2024
Respectfully
Submitted, 
LIUNA
Minnesota
&
North
Dakota
By:
Kevin
Pranis 
Marketing
Manager 
81
Little
Canada
Road 
St.
Paul,
MN
55117

On Behalf Of: IUOE LOCAL 49 AND NCSRC OF CARPENTERS
content:
Comments
from
Operating
Engineers
Local
49
and
North
Central
States
Regional
Council
of
Carpenters
Aug
26,
2024
Mr.
Will
Seuffert
Executive
Secretary
Minnesota
Public
Utilities
Commission
121
7th
Place
East,
Suite
350
St.
Paul,
MN
55101
RE:
In
the
Matter
of
the
Petition
of
Minnesota
Power
for
the
Acquisition
of
Allete
by
Canada
Pension
Plan
Investment
Board
and
Global
Infrastructure
Partners
Dear
Mr.
Seuffert,
We
appreciate
the
opportunity
to
submit
reply
comments
in
the
above
matter.
As
the
Public
Utilities
Commission
(Commission)
is
aware,
our
unions
represent
construction
workers
who
perform
construction
and
maintenance
work
on
Minnesota
Power’s
system.
Our
members
work
for
union
signatory
contractors
who
are
hired
by
Allete
to
perform
this
work.
Minnesota
Power
has
had
a
longstanding
commitment
to
utilizing
skilled,
local
workers
for
the
construction
and
maintenance
of
their
energy
infrastructure.
This
has
resulted
in
significant
work
hours
for
union
construction
workers
and
has
benefited
our
members
in
northeastern
Minnesota.
We
appreciate
the
stated
intention
in
the
present
application
to
continue
with
current
contracting
practices
and
deploy
union
labor
wherever
reasonably
possible.
As
the
Commission
is
aware,
the
ongoing
energy
transition
and
potential
for
increased
load
growth
will
likely
require
significant
amounts
of
new
energy
infrastructure
to
be
deployed
in
the
coming
decades.
The
proposed
acquisition,
if
approved,
would
likely
ensure
stable
access
to
the
capital
needed
to
support
the
infrastructure
investment
needed.
We
anticipate
the
Commission
will
send
this
matter
to
an
Administrative
Law
Judge
and
we
plan
to
participate
in
that
proceeding.
Sincerely,
Nathan
Runke,
Regulatory
and
Political
Affairs
Coordinator,
International
Union
of
Operating
Engineers
Local
49
Richard
Kolodziejski,
Public
Affairs
Director,
North
Central
States
Regional
Council
of
Carpenters

332 Minnesota Street, Suite W1360  
Saint Paul, MN 55101 
www.cubminnesota.org  
info@cubminnesota.org, 651 -300- 4701

1 STATE OF MINNESOTA  
PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
   Katie Sieben    Chair  
   Hwikwon Ham    Commissioner  
Valerie Means    Commissioner  
   Joseph Sullivan    Commissioner  
   John Tuma    Commissioner  
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for 
the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  Docket No. E- 015/PA -24-198 
 
Reply Comments of the Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota  
The Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota (“CUB”) respectfully submits these Reply  Comments in 
response to the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission’s (“Commission”) Notice of Comment  Period 
issued  on July 23 , 202 41 and initial comments filed on August 19, 2024. The Notice requests comments 
on Minnesota Power’s June 19, 2024 petition (the “Petition”) seeking approval of a proposed 
acquisition involving ALLETE, Inc., the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board , and Global 
Infrastructure Partners  (the “Proposed Transaction”). CUB continues to  recommend that the 
Commission  refer this matter to the OAH for  a contested case proceeding , and we request that the 
Commission  grant CUB’s petition to intervene as a party in th at proceeding.  We also respond to a few 
additional comments and recommendations offered by other parties, as discussed below.  
 
A. The Commission should allow adequate time for a contested case proceeding.  
 
The Petition includes proposed target dates that establishes a general timeline for a contested case 
proceeding.5 The timeline contemplates (among other deadlines) evidentiary hearings in mid-
December 2024, an ALJ Report by March 12, 2025 and a Commission Order by June 16, 2025.    
  
We agree with the Office of the Attorney General – Residential Utilities Division (“OAG”) that t his 
timeline seems too ambitious.2 In order for evidentiary hearings to occur in mid- December, expert 
witnesses would need to prepare and file testimony on a highly accelerated basis. Also, a mid -
December evidentiary hearing overlaps with a December 18 -20, 2024 evidentiary hearing already 
scheduled in the CenterPoint rate case, to which CUB is a party.  
 
1 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global 
Infrastructure Partners, Notice of  Comment Period , Docket  No. E-15/PA -24-198 ( July 23, 2024)  (“Commission Notice”)  
2 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Gl obal 
Infrastructure Partners, OAG Initial Comments, Docket No. E -15/PA -24-198 (August 19, 2024), p.  10. 
 
2  
We support  the OAG’s proposal for the Commission to  adopt a schedule  with a later deadline for an 
ALJ Report and that will otherwise ”permit robust development of the record while still allowing the 
transaction to be consummated by February 5, 2026, should it be approved. ”3 
 
B. The Commission should require the Company to file additional information on how it 
intends to comply with affiliated interest filing requirement s. 
 
According to the Petition, “[t]he  Company does not anticipate the need for approval of affiliated 
interest contracts or agreements pursuant to  Minn. R. 7825.2200 because ALLETE and its subsidiary 
structure are not changing. ”4 The Department  questions this conclusion, noting several discrepancies 
or potential points of confusion raised in the Petition pertaining t o affiliate interest agreements.5 The 
Department also raises concerns about the Company’s lack of discussion on existing contracts that 
may become affiliated interest agreements if both the Proposed Transaction and  BlackRock/GIP 
acquisition successfully close. To help address these concerns,  the Department recommends that the 
Commission require Minnesota Power to supplement its Petition by November 1, 2024 with a filing 
that comprehensively addresses the potential affiliate status of the portfolio company holdings of the 
Partners and BlackRock .6 
 We generally agree that the Petition does not adequately explain how the Company will address 
affiliated interests that arise if the Proposed Transaction is approved, and if BlackRock’s acquisition of 
GIP also closes. Even if ALLETE and its subsidiary stru cture is not changing, the ownership structure 
above ALLETE will obviously look quite different if the Proposed Transaction is approved:  
7  
 
 
3 OAG Initial Comments at 11.  
4 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Gl obal 
Infrastructure Partners, Minnesota Power Petition, Docket No. E -15/PA -24-198 ( July 19, 2024), p. 24, FN 28.  
5 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Gl obal 
Infrastructure Partners, Department Initial Comments, Docket No. E -15/PA -24-198 (August 19, 2024), p.  5-6. 
6 Id. at 6. 
7 Petition at Attachment A -2. 
 
3  
This raises reasonable questions as to whether ALLETE, Inc./Minnesota Power will be affiliated with 
other entities owned directly or indirectly by GIP and CPP (and, ultimately, BlackRock)  and how the 
Company will comply  with reporting requirements under Minn. Stat. 216B.48 and Minn. R. 7825.2200 .  
 
While we  have not had sufficient time since initial comments were filed to fully consider the 
Department’s recommendation , we share the Department’s concerns . We agree that it would be 
helpful for the Company to explain in more detail how it plans to determine what affiliated interests 
must be reported pursuant to Minn. Stat. 216B.48 and Minn. R. 7825.2200 , as well as how the 
definition of affiliated interest found in Minn. Stat. 216B.48 does or does not align with the definition 
of “affiliate” included in the Merger Agreement enclosed with the Petition.8   
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
8 See Petition at Attachment B, p. 103.  

 
4 CONCLUSION  
 
In summary, CUB continues to recommend that the Commission refer this matter to the OAH for a 
contested case proceeding, and we request that the Commission grant CUB’s petition to intervene as 
a party in that proceeding. We also now recommend that the Commission extend the deadline for an 
ALJ Report (beyond what was proposed in the Petition) to allow for robust record development, and 
that the Commission require the Company to explain in more detail how it intends to comply with 
affiliated interest reporting requirements, should the Proposed Transaction be approved.  
 
Thank you for considering our comments.  
 Sincerely,

IN THE MATTER OF THE PETITION OF 
MINNESOTA POWER FOR ACQUISITION 
OF ALLETE BY CANADA PENSION PLAN 
INVESTMENT BOARD AND GLOBAL 
INFRASTRUCTURE PARTNERS   
  
REPLY COMMENTS  
 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 
I. INTRODUCTION  
On July 19, 2024, Minnesota Power filed with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 
its Petition for Approval of the Acquisition of the Company by entities controlled or managed by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (collectively “CPP Investments”) and Global 
Infrastructure Partners (collectively “GIP”) (together, t he “Partners”) through a new Partner -
created entity known as Alloy Parent LLC (“Parent”) (the “Acquisition”). On July 23, 2024, the 
Commission issued a Notice of Comment Period seeking comments on the following topics:  
• Has Minnesota Power’s filing complied with all filing requirements under 
Minnesota Statute §  216B.50 and Minnesota Rules 7825.1700 and 7825.1800?  
• Should this matter be referred to the Office of Administrative Hearings (“OAH”) 
for a contested case proceeding and, if so, what issues will require record 
development?  
• Are there other issues or concerns related to this matter?  
The Notice of Comment Period set a deadline for initial comments of August 19, 2024. 
The Minnesota Office of the Attorney General – Residential Utilities  Division (“ OAG ”), the 
Minnesota Department of Commerce, Division of Energy Resources (the “Department”), the 
Citizens Utility Board (“CUB”), the Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”), and the International 
 2 Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local 31 (“Local 31”) filed comments (collectively, “the 
Comments”) by the deadline established by the Commission. Minnesota Power responds to the 
Comments in accordance with the Commission’s Notice of Comment Period, allowing for reply 
comments to be filed through August 26, 2024.  
As an initial matter, Minnesota Power1 appreciate s the interest in the proceedings and 
observes several common themes among the parties’ Comments:  An interest in a greater 
understanding of the role of investors in the Parent; a desire to develop further information 
regarding the relative pros and cons of the Acquisition ; and thoughts on the appropriate procedural 
process and schedule for the review of the Acquisition . As discussed in more detail below, the 
applicants agree these are reasonable areas of interest when properly framed.  Additional 
information can be developed through an efficient, effective Administrative Law Judge -directed 
process, whic h the Company supports.   
However, the Comments to date require underscoring that while the Acquisition , would 
result in ALLETE shares no longer being traded on the New York st ock exchange, Minnesota 
Power (1) will remain a Minnesota public utility in its current form  and subject to the 
Commission’s regulatory authority;  (2) will remain within the same ALLETE structure and family 
of companies ; and (3) will continue to be owned by investors.  It is beneficial to customers that the 
Partners, as ALLETE’s post-Acquisition investors , will be experienced infrastructure investment 
entities, chosen by  ALLETE because they are investing  for the long term, understand the energy 
industry, support the Company’s values and vision to meet Minnesota’s clean energy goals  while 
continuing to supply safe, reliable, and affordable electric service , and have the capability to 
finance the Company’s capital needs  going forward . This financing capability will support the 
 
1 The Partners share in these Reply Comments, and join Minnesota Power in the discussion provided herein.  
 3 Company’s ability to continue to make the large investments necessary to decarbonize its system 
while maintain ing safe, reliable service for its customers. W hile the C omments focus on whether 
there are customer benefits in the form of cost or rate savings, these are not the purpose of th e 
Acquisition (as discussed  below) . Moreover, as the Commission has recognized, cost savings are 
not the only type of benefit of a merger or acquisition ; rather, benefits can exist in many forms, 
including but not limited to  reduced risk , more stable  and adaptive funding , additional expertise , 
or potential improved buying power.2 Likewise, imposing net savings requirements, rather than 
relying on the existing statutory public interest standard for merger, could have adverse impacts.3  
Ultimately, the Company  and Partners  support a contested case process to further develop 
the record to determine whether the proposed Acquisition is consistent with the  public interest , 
and consider the timelines proposed by the Department to be reasonable.  We respond to the 
Comments on the Commission’s identified questions below.  
II. HAS MINNESOTA POWER’S FILING COMPLIED WITH ALL FILING 
REQUIREMENTS UNDER MINNESOTA STATUTE §  216B.50 AND MINNESOTA 
RULES 7825.1700 AND 7825.1800?  
In its Notice of Comment Period, the Commission sought comments on whether the 
Company’s Petition complied with all filing requirements of Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and Minnesota 
Rules 7825.1700 and 7825.1800.  OAG, LPI, and Local 31 do not appear to take a direct position 
on this question.  CUB acknowledges that the Petition appears to meet the requirements of the 
 
2 See, e.g.,  In the Matter of a Request for Approval of the Merger Agreement Between Integrys Energy Group, Inc. 
and Wisconsin Energy Corporation  (“Integrys/WEC Merger ”), Docket No. G-011/PA -14-664, ORDER APPROVING 
MERGER SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS  (“INTEGRYS /WEC  ORDER ”) at 8-9 (June 25, 2015 ) (“MERC has argued 
persuasively that the goal of the merger is not to achieve immediate synergies but rather to better position the merged 
companies to access capital and invest in infrastructure and customer -service improvements. Moreover, any 
operational  or capital -cost savings realized should benefit ratepayers through reduced rates. Under these 
circumstances, the public interest does not require that MERC demonstrate any particular level of savings as a result 
of the merger. The Commission also notes th at the Xcel –New Century merger, on which the Commission imposed a 
cost-savings condition, was predicated in large part on obtaining savings by consolidating programs and reducing 
staff. In contrast, in this case the merging companies have not identified a need for workforce reductions, and MERC 
has committed not to make any workforce reductions for at least two years.”).  
3 See id.  
 4 applicable statute and rules, but that additional information is needed to assess the Acquisition . 
The Department indicates that the Petition meets these requirements as to GIP and CPP  
Investments , but requests more information regarding the application of th e statutes and rules to 
BlackRock  Inc. (“BlackRock”)  in light of its proposed acquisition of GIP.  Additionally, the 
Department goes so far as to suggest that an entity with a controlling financial interest in a public 
utility is itself a public utility under Minn. Stat. § 216B.02, subd. 4, which in turn gives rise to the 
Department’s request for more information regarding both GIP and BlackRock.   
Minnesota Power and the Partners recognize the interest in BlackRock and will provide 
more information in Direct Testimony and through the discovery process. However,  the Petition 
includes information identified in  Minnesota statute and rule.  For that reason,  it is important to 
address these Comments to illustrate why the Petition is structured as it is , to clarify that the 
Petition includes the required information,  and to properly frame the ultimate issues before the 
Commission.  
Minnesota statutes both define what constitutes a “public utility” in the state and the 
Commission’s role in regulating public utilities.  Under Minn. Stat. § 216B.02, subd. 4, a public 
utility is defined (with certain inapplicable exceptions) as “ persons, corporations, or other legal 
entities, their lessees, trustees, and receivers, now or hereafter operating, maintaining, or 
controlling in this state equipment or facilities for furnishing at retail natural, manufactured, or 
mixed gas or electric service to or for the public or engaged in the production and retail sale 
thereof .” (Emphasis added .) Notably, this statute speaks to controlling the equipment or facilities 
providing the electric service, as Minnesota Power does, rather than holders of a financial interest 
in the holding company in which the public utility resides . Many statutes within the Mi nnesota 
regulatory construct depend on the public utility being the entity that controls the equipment or 
 5 facilities providing electric or gas service; otherwise, the Commission would be regulating the 
rates, services, service standards, and policies4 of any entity with a financial interest in a public 
utility, regardless of whether that entity was in fact providing utility service – which is plainly 
unworkable for the Commission.  
Consistent with Minnesota law, the Commission has never considered or treated  a public 
utility holding company, much less  investor s in a public utility holding company  as a regulated 
public utility. For example, while Minnesota Power is a division of ALLETE, the Commission 
regulates the Minnesota Power operating utility; not the unregulated subsidiaries of ALLETE or 
affiliates of Minnesota Power  directly . In other merger dockets , the Commission  has also explicitly 
identified  public utility holding companies  as holding companies  even if they had a  subsidiary 
public utility .5 Rather, information that is relevant is addressed in relation to the public  utility (such 
as through capital structure and affiliated interest filings) . There would be no need for Minnesota’s 
affiliated interest  laws and rules6 if public utility holding companies were in fact public utilities  
such that the Commission regulated them directly .  
Financial investors in a public utility holding company, such as the Partners  (in relation to 
the Alloy Parent and ALLETE, Inc.) , are even further removed from the public utility than the 
holding company itself.  For example, the Commission does not consider the current shareholders 
of public utility holding companies to themselves be “public utilities.”  While both public 
shareholders  and like private investors, in a utility holding company select and approve the board 
 
4 See, e.g. , Minn. Stat. § 216B.09, subds. 2 -3.  
5 See, e.g. , In the Matter of the Petition by Interstate Power Company for Approval to Merge with IES Industries, Inc. 
and WPL Holdings, Inc. , Docket No. E, G-001/PA -96-184, ORDER APPROVING MERGER WITH CONDITIONS  (Mar. 24, 
1997 ); In the Matter of the Proposed Merger of Midwest Energy, Inc. and Iowa Resources, Inc.; In the Matter of the 
Proposed Merger of Iowa Public Service Company and Iowa Power, Inc. , Docket No. G010/DI -90-1144; G010/PA -
91-728, ORDER APPROVING MERGERS AND REQUIRING FURTHER FILINGS  (Jan. 21, 1992 ); See INTEGRYS /WEC  ORDER  
at 2. 
6 Minn. Stat. §  216B.48 . 
 6 of directors for the holding company, neither the public shareholders nor private investors operat e 
the utility  or the facilities and equipment providing service . In turn, shareholders of utility holding 
company are often institutional investors (such as BlackRock Fund Advisors (a subsidiary of 
BlackRock) and The Vanguard  Group, Inc.  presently are for ALLETE  and other Minnesota public 
utilities ). These institutional investors may  in turn may have further upstream investors.7 These 
investors are increasingly removed from the public utility entity and, again, maintain a financial 
investment rather than an operating role in the utility.  Similarly, the upstream contributors to and 
beneficiaries of the Canada Pension Plan and upstream investors  of GIP (including BlackRock, if 
the transaction is approved ) are significantly attenuated from the Minnesota Power utility and 
functions , as they are  solely financial investor s in the parent entities . 
Conversely, and as noted in the Petition, if the Acquisition is approved Minnesota Power 
will retain its structure, role in the ALLETE family of companies, and status as a Minnesota 
Commission -regulated, investor -owned public utility.  In short, the Company’s Petition seeks 
approval solely of a change in investors, and the post -closing investors will not be  “public utilities”

hand. Likewise, question 4 is framed as if there are necessarily harms, costs, or risks such that

D. The Commission has a well -established standard of review for mergers and 
acquisitions of public utilities and public utility holding companies.  
While an ALJ Report in a contested case process will set forth conclusions of law as to the 
standard of review for this matter, t he standard  before this Commission  with respect to mergers 
and acquisitions  is well established . Specifically, Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 , subd. 1  states : 
No public utility shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or 
system in this state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000, or merge or 
consolidate with another public utility or transmission company operating in this 
state, without first being authorized so to do by the commission. ... If the 
commission finds that the proposed action is consistent with the public interest , it 
shall give its consent and approval by order in writing. In reaching its 
determination, the comm ission shall take into consideration the reasonable value of 
the property, plant, or securities to be acquired or disposed of, or merged and 
consolidated.  
(Emphasis added).  This provision requires  Commission approval of a  merger  or acquisition  upon 
a showing that the  merger is “consistent with  the public interest .” The statute itself does not list 
specific criteria that the Commission must consider or findings that it must make when determining 
the public interest . However, this legal standard has been consistently described and applied over 
many years.  
 
19 Id. at 6. 
20 CUB Initial Comments at 3.  
 15 As discussed in the Petition, and c ontrary to the assertions  in the Comments , the 
Commission has concluded  that the statute “does not require that  proposed mergers affirmatively 
benefit ratepayers or the public or that they otherwise promote the public interest. ”21 Rather, to 
determine  if the proposed merger is  “consistent with  the public interest ,” the perceived detriments  
simply  must not outweigh the  perceived benefits .22 While a proposed merger  cannot contravene 
the public interest,  it need only be shown to  be compatible with it  to warrant approval .23 The FERC 
has similarly defined its “consistent with the public interest standard,” noting in its Merger Policy 
Statement that “consistent with the public interest” is a “do no harm” standard, not a net benefit 
standard.24 
Further, a ny benefits from the proposed Acquisition are not required to  take the form of  
cost savings  or rate reductions . While the Commission has approved some mergers where financial 
benefits for customers  have been anticipated ,25 the Commission has  also approved  mergers  focused 
on other  types of  benefits . For example, such benefits have included  increased financial 
capability26 and interest in ownership of  certain utility assets .27 Public interest benefits can include 
enhancing a utility’s ability to achieve public policy goals and meet statutory requirements related 
to reliability and carbon reduction to address climate change.  
Additionally, LPI and  CUB ’s arguments that a  higher or modified  standard of review 
should be applied  in this case are unsupported . The Commission itself has stated that  it “has 
consistently evaluated mergers of energy utilities using the standard prescribed by Minn. Stat.

23 NSP/NEW CENTURY ORDER  at 7; see IPL/MERC  ORDER  at 2, 5. 
24 Inquiry Concerning the Commission’s Merger Policy Under the Federal Power Act: Policy Statement , 77 FERC ¶ 
61,263 , at PP 92-93 (1996).  
25 See id.  at PP 11-12. 
26 See INTEGRYS /WEC  ORDER  at 2. 
27 See IPL/MERC  ORDER  at 2 (noting that, under the facts of that case, “increased rates alone are insufficient to

 16 § 216B.50 (consistent with the public interest) .”28 There is also no merit to  the suggestion that this  
standard is outdated, as this  standard has been applied in several recent cases  and directly reflects 
the statutory standard .29 
Because this well -established standard presents an area of legal inquiry, Minnesota Power 
respectfully submits that the Commission need not take action to address this standard at this time . 
Rather, the ALJ Report will likely include a Standard of Review discussion for Commission review 
and consideration. Further, t he pros and cons of the  Acquisition  will be addressed throughout this 
proceeding .

C. The subject matter of the Acquisition can be further evaluated during the 
contested  case proceeding.  
OAG -RUD  and CUB  question whether the Acquisition is in the public interest , and raise 
several concerns and questions about costs and benefits of the proposed Acquisition.  Such 
questions can and should be fleshed out over the course of this proceeding , starting with Direct 
Testimony provided by ALLETE and the Partners.  
One concern raised by the OAG and CUB is  a perception of benefit to shareholders without 
perceiving equal benefits to customers.  Importantly, even if this were the case the “consistent with 
the public interest” standard does not necessarily contemplate equal benefits for every stakeholder, 
nor a balancing of shareholder and customer or public interest benefits. Rather, it contemplates a 
showing that the Acquisition will not harm the public interest.  
That said, as noted earlier in these Reply Comments, th e purpose of this Acquisition is to  
further the public interest in safe, reliable, and increasingly carbon -free service in a progressively 
more  challenging business and natural environment. If approved, the Acquisition will benefit 
customers and the public interest by strengthen ing and expand ing Minnesota Power’s ability to 
finance the investments  it must make to continue converting the utility’s generation, transmission, 
and distribution systems to be cleaner, more resilient, and better able to withstand the challenges 
of increasing renewable energy, increasing customer electrification and demands  on the system, 
and the changing climate conditions  that are testing utility systems across the country.  
As noted in the Petition, ALLETE  is the largest investor in renewable energy , relative to 
market capitalization , of all publicly traded utilities in the  United States .33 In particular, Minnesota

For Minnesota Power, all this must happen in a manner that supports the Company’s unique

a. Determine that it is not necessary to make a finding of “completeness” in order to 
refer the matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings  
[OR]  
b. Determine that the Petition satisfies Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 
7825.1700 and Minn. R. 7825.1800 as to the parties to the Acquisition.  
2. Refer this matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case and 
request the Administrative Law Judge’s Report by June 15, 2025 with the following 
issues to be developed in the record:  
a. Are there any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed transaction, 
including in relation to cost or risk?  
b. Are there any potential benefits to the public interest from the proposed 
transaction, including in relation to cost or risk?  
c. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction 
consistent with the public interest?  
d. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments necessary to render the 
proposed transaction consistent with the public interest?  
e. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy 
Regulatory Commission, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin , and/or other 
state, federal or foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s 
consideration of the proposed transaction?  
3. Direct Minnesota Power to include in Direct Testimony the following discussion, to the 
extent not already addressed in the Petition o r these Reply Comments:  
 
a. a detailed explanation of whether the pending acquisition of certain interests in 
Global Infrastructure Partners by BlackRock, Inc. requires Commission 
authorization under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023), and if not, why not;  
 23  
b. a discussion of affiliated interest issues that may or may not arise between 
ALLETE and subsidiaries  or affiliates  of Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
or Global Infrastructure Partner s. 
 
4. Determine that it is necessary for the Department to obtain specialized technical 
professional investigative services pursuant to Minn. Stat. 216B.62, subd. 8 to assist the 
Department in its review  regarding the “complex legal structure” of the Acquisition and 
“the nature of ALLETE’s potential acquirers ,” and direct the Department to obtain  these  
services in such time that does not delay a Report from the Administrative Law Judge on 
or before June 16, 2025 .

STATE OF MINNESOTA  
BEFORE THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
Katie Sieben  Chair  
Joseph K. Sullivan  Vice C hair 
Hwikwon Ham  Commissioner  
Valerie Means  Commissioner  
John Tuma  Commissioner  
 
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and 
Global Infrastructure Partners  DOCKET NO. E-015/PA -24-198 
 
COMMENTS OF THE OFFICE OF  
THE ATTORNEY GENERAL  
 
INTRODUCTION  
The Office of the Attorney General —Residential Utilities Division (OAG) respectfully 
submits the following Comments  on the proposed acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. by Global 
Infrastructure Partners (Global) and Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (Canada Pension) .  
The Commission’s July 23, 2024 Notice of Comment Period requests comment on whether the 
transaction should be referred to the Office of Administrative Hearings  (OAH)  for a contested -
case proceeding  and, if so, what issues require record development.  For the reasons explained 
below, the Commission should refer the matter for contested -case proceedings to develop the 
record on whether the proposed transaction is in the public interest.  
BACKGROUND  
I. THE PARTIES AND PROPOSED TRANSACTION  
ALLETE, Inc. is  a publicly traded energy firm headquartered in Duluth.  ALLETE’s largest 
division is Minnesota Power, an electric utility also based in Duluth.  Minnesota Power has the 
exclusive right to provide retail electric service  in a 26,000- square -mile area of central and 
northern Minnesota .  The utility’s ratepayers include  150,000 residents, 14 municipalities, and 
several large industrial customers , including taconite mines and wood- products manufacturers.  
2 
 Global is an infrastructure investor that “specializes in investing in, owning, and/or 
operating some of the largest and most complex assets across the energy, transport, digital 
infrastructure, and water and waste management sectors.”1  Global ha d approximately $115 billion 
in assets under management as of March 31, 2024.2  Global is itself in the process of being acquired 
by BlackRock, one of the world’s largest asset managers with more than $10 trillion in assets under management.
3 
Canada Pension manages pension funds on behalf of 22 million Canadians.4  As of 
March  31, 2024, C anada Pension  managed assets totaling C$632 billion, including approximately 
US$198 billion invested directly and indirectly in public and private real estate, infrastructure, and 
energy companies in the United States.5 
On May 6, 2024, ALLETE announced that a partnership led by Global and Canada Pension 
had agreed to acquire ALLETE for $67 per share, or $6.2 billion including the assumption of debt.6  
According to ALLETE, this price represents “a premium of approximately 19.1% to ALLETE’s 
closing share price on December 4, 2023, the date prior to a media article reporting that ALLETE was exploring a sale” and a 22.1% premium to the 30- day volume -weighted average 
share price prio r to December 4.
7  If consummated, the proposed transaction would take ALLETE

Markets Surge, Reuters (Apr. 12, 2024), https://www.reuters.com/markets/us/blackrocks- first-
quarter- profit- rises-higher- fee-income-2024-04- 12/.

7 Id.  
3 
 from a publicly traded company owned by many investors  to a privately held company controlled 
by two principal investors. 
II. PETITION  FOR COMMISSION  APPROVAL  
On, July 19, 2024, ALLETE, Global , and Canada Pension  (collectively, “Applicants”) filed 
their petition seeking  the Commission’s a pproval  of the proposed transaction under Minnesota 
Statutes section 216B.50.   
Under the proposed transaction, Global  and Canada Pension  would acquire, through a 
jointly owned entity known as Alloy Parent LLC, all shares of ALLETE.8  The transaction is 
structured as a merger, whereby Merger Sub, a wholly owned subsidiary of Alloy Parent, w ould 
merge with and into ALLETE, with ALLETE continuing as the surviving corporation and 
becom ing a subsidiary of Alloy Parent.9  According to Applicants, the “primary goal of 
transitioning to a private company is to enable Minnesota Power to obtain the significant additional 
capital it needs to continue and expand its investment in clean energy technology and systems.”10  
Applicants  further state that the acquisition “is expected to benefit customers by offering ALLETE 
better alternatives to the volatility and inflexible demands of the capital marketplace when financing is needed.”
11 
The petition outlines several contractual commitments in the merger agreement that 
Applicants argue  underscore their “dedication to supporting employees, customers, and 
communities, meeting State policy goals, and providing safe, reliable, and reasonably priced electric service to customers.”
12  These commitments include:  
 
8 Id. at 1.  
9 Id. at 31.  
10 Id. at 2.  
11 Id. 
12 Id. at 17.  
4 
 • maintaining the headquarters of Minnesota Power in Duluth;  
• honoring union contracts;  
• maintaining the current senior management team;  
• maintaining historic levels of economic development and charitable 
contributions;  
• maintaining corporate separateness (i.e., ring -fencing) between ALLETE and 
Alloy Parent; 
• not attempting to recover the acquisition premium from utility customers;  
• not attempting to recover the costs of executing the transaction from utility customers;  
• not attempting to recover any transition costs from utility customers except to 
the extent the transition costs produce savings;  
• using commercially reasonable efforts to maintain Minnesota Power’s 
debt/equity ratios and its corporate and facility ratings;  
• not reducing the overall scope or resources dedicated to affordability programs; and 
• continuing to provide the Commission access to Minnesota Power’s books and 
records.
13 
ANALYSIS  
Under Minnesota Statutes section 216B.50, the Commission may not approve a merger or 
acquisition  unless it finds  that the transaction is consistent with the public interest.14  In evaluating 
whether a proposed transaction is consistent with the public interest, the Commission considers its 
potential benefits and harms.15  If the potential harms of a transaction outweigh the potential 
benefits, the transaction is not consistent with the public interest unless  conditions are imposed 
that sufficiently  mitigate th e harm s.16 
 
13 Id. at 18–22.  
14 See Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, subd. 1. 
15 In re Proposed Merger of Minnegasco, Inc. with and into Arkla, Inc., Docket No. G -008/PA -
90-604, Order Approving Merger and Adopting Amended Stipulation with Modifications at 4 
(Nov. 27, 1990) [hereinafter Minnegasco  Order ].   
16 See In re Petition by N. States Power Co. for Approval of the Acquisition of the Mankato Energy 
Ctr., Docket No. E -002/PA -18-702, Order Denying Petition and Requiring Supplemental 
(Footnote Continued on Next Page)  
5 
 The evidence available at this time, which consists entirely of Applicants’ petition and 
attachments, raises questions  about whether the proposed transaction would harm ratepayers and 
the public interest and whether any benefits the transaction may have would offset those harms.  
Accordingly, the Commission should refer the petition to OAH to help determine whether the 
proposed transaction is consistent with the public interest .17 
I. IT IS UNCLEAR WHETHER THE PROPOSED TRANSACTION IS CONSISTENT WITH THE 
PUBLIC INTEREST . 
It is not yet clear whether G lobal  and C anada Pension ’s proposed acquisition of ALLETE 
is consistent with the public interest because the potential benefits and harms have not been developed.  In the past, the Commission has identified as benefits things like rate decreases, rate freezes, distributed -generation aggregation, increased low -income assistance, CO
2 mitigation,18 
and cost savings through economies of scale and improved financing capabilities.19  Potential 
transaction -related harms that the Commission has cited in past cases include:  
• transaction -related costs,  
• service- quality impairment,  
• loss of regulatory oversight,  
• reduced competition,20 
 
Modeling  at 9–10 (Dec. 18, 2019)  (concluding that acquisition was not consistent with the public 
interest because “t he potential costs to ratepayers are too high, and the potential benefits too 
uncertain, to support the purchase ”); Minnegasco Order at 6 (“Having balanced possible benefits 
with possible costs, noting the safeguards adopted by the parties and required by this Order, the 
Commission finds that the merger between Arkla and Minnegasco is consistent with the public interest.”).  
17 See Minn. R. 7829.1000 (“If a proceeding involves contested material facts and there is a right 
to a hearing under statute or rule, or if the commission finds that all significant issues have not been resolved to its satisfaction, the commission shall refer the matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings for contested case proceedings . . . .” ). 
18 See In re Application of N. States Power Co. for Approval to Merge with New Century Energies, 
Inc., Docket No. E,G -002/PA -99-1031, Order Approving Merger, as Conditioned at 11–12 (June 
12, 2000) [hereinafter NSP –New Century  Order ]. 
19 Minnegasco Order at 4.  
20 See NSP –New Century  Order at 12 n.5. 
6 
 • an acquirer’s debt or speculative ventures,  
• cross- subsidization and self -dealing,  
• ratepayer underwriting of acquisition adjustments and goodwill, and  
• increased complexity of ensuring ratepayer protection.21 
It is clear that the proposed transaction carries risks for ratepayers.  What is less clear is 
what, if any, benefits it holds for ratepayers and whether those benefits outweigh the risks.  
A. The Proposed Transaction Carries Risks for Ratepayers.  
This proposed transaction implicates many of the same concerns as past mergers the 
Commission has considered, as well as additional concerns that the Commission has not yet faced.   
If the transaction is consummated, ALLETE and Minnesota Power will become 
subsidiaries of G lobal  and Canada Pension.  Global  is itself set to be acquired by BlackRock, one 
of the world’s largest asset managers.  All of these entities have numerous other investments in 
energy and nonenergy industries, presenting opportunities for  cross -subsidization and self -dealing 
that could  harm Minnesota Power’s ratepayers and the public interest more broadly.  
Moreover, the investment goals and strategies of the new owners likely  differ from those 
of ALLETE’s current owners.  The fact that Global and Canada Pension are willing to pay a 19 to 
22 percent premium above ALLETE’s market price suggests that they see significant value in 
controlling ALLETE’s management and investment strategy.  The buyers will be expecting to 
recover their initial investment along with significant returns.  And they presumably expect to recover much of that investment and return from Minnesota Power, ALLETE’s largest division and a source of captive ratepayer revenue.
22

 Additional concerns arise from the loss of transparency  and changed dynamics  due to  
taking ALLETE private.  While Minnesota Power is agreeing to provide some information 
voluntarily,23 it is unclear whether this voluntary cooperation will be as enforceable as those 
disclosure obligations that are required by the federal government and stock exchanges for publicly 
traded companies.  Minnesota Power will also go from being the largest component of ALLETE’s 
operations to a minor part of the vast investment portfolios of Global and Canadian Pension—as well as potentially BlackRock.  The decreased relevance of Minnesota Power may have negative implications for its ratepayers, Minnesota, and the public interest.  
These are just a few examples of the risks presented by the proposed change in control of 
ALLETE.  It is not possible to discern the magnitude of the potential harms or the likelihood of their occurrence based on solely on the petition.  A contested case is therefore necessary to fully 
develop the record and allow  the Commission to make an informed determination about whether 
the proposed transaction is in the public interest.  
B. The Proposed Transaction Would Benefit Shareholders b ut Appears to Have 
Few i f Any Benefits for Ratepayers.  
As with  the transaction’s potential  harms, it is impossible to determine based on the petition 
alone what benefits the proposed transaction holds for ratepayers and the public, or whether any benefits outweigh the potential  harm s.  While the petition references several contractual 
commitments, these commitments are generally limited to maintaining conditions as they exist 
today.
24  Maintaining the status quo, however, is not a “benefit .”  At best, these commitments 
attempt to mitigate the risks of transferring control of Minnesota Power  to new owners.   
 
this Commission has established here in Minnesota ,” which provides “ the foundation for an 
attractive investment, and that ’s why we ’re committing so much capital to it”).  
23 Petition at 20.  
24 See id. at 18 –22. 
8 
 The petition also states that the proposed transaction would “offer [] ALLETE better 
alternatives to the volatility and inflexible demands of the capital marketplace when financing is 
needed.”25  Yet Applicants  do not identify any monetary benefit of this improved access to capital 
or commit to sharing any capital -cost savings with ratepayers.  
In contrast  to the lack of ratepayer benefits, the transaction provides a significant benefit 
to ALLETE’s executives and shareholders through the 19 to 22 percent market premium.   For 
example, ALLETE’s CEO directly or indirectly owned nearly 40,000 shares of the company as of 
February 2024.26  Thus, if the proposed transaction is consummated, the CEO would receive more 
than $2.6 million for her current shares of ALLETE.27  Additionally, Black Rock is one of 
ALLETE’s largest shareholders, with a 13.5 percent  ownership stake as of December 31, 2023.28   
If the proposed transaction  is consummated, BlackRock stands to receive roughly $522 million  for 
its current shares of ALLETE.29  Meanwhile, as a result of its pending acquisition of Global, 
BlackRock would increase its ownership stake in ALLETE from 13.5 percent to 60 percent .30 
II. THE COMMISSION SHOULD REFER THE MATTER TO OAH  FOR A CONTESTED -CASE 
PROCEEDING . 
Applicants’ petition  should be referred to OAH to develop the record on the potential harms 
and benefits, along with any other issues of material fact.  A contested case would also allow interested parties the right to discovery, create a disciplined record, and result in an ALJ recommendation to assist the Commission ’s deliberations.

 Notably, Applicants  propose an evidentiary hearing on December 17 –19, 2024, which 
would overlap with the evidentiary hearing in the CenterPoint rate case, scheduled for 
December  18–20.32  This overlap between the two evidentiary hearings  is unworkable for the OAG 
and likely for other potential intervenors in this case.  Rather than specifying a detailed schedule 
in its referral order, the Commission should do what it normally does in contested cases : request 
that the administrative law judge  (ALJ) issue a  report by a specified date.  The parties and the ALJ 
can then work backwards from that date to plan out the contested -case schedule.    
Given the unprecedented nature of the proposed transaction and other matters pending 
before the Commission,  Applicants’ proposal  to have an ALJ report by mid- March 2025 is  
unreasonable .  This deadline will likely need to be pushed back several  months  to allow enough 
time for the parties and ALJ to develop a record for Commission decision.  The OAG looks forward 
to hearing other parties’ thoughts on a workable timeframe.   
In determining a timeframe for decision , the Commission should keep in mind that 
Applicants’ merger agreement contemplates the  August 5, 2025 closing deadline (or “ end date”)  
being extended by up to six months if additional time is needed for regulatory review .33  Consistent 
with this contractual provision,  Applicants’  petition states that “the Commission will want to 
undertake a robust process of evaluating the proposed transaction with the input of interested stakeholders  [and]  will require sufficient time to do so ” and that Applicants “ have committed, and 
continue to commit, to providing the Commission with the time it requires to evaluate the petition

I. INTRODUCTION  
On July 19 , 2024 Minnesota Power (or “ the Company ”) submitted  a petition ( “Petition ”) to the 
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission ( “Commission ”) requesting an order approv ing the acquisition  
(“Acquisition ”) of ALLETE, Inc.  (“ALLETE”) , Minnesota Power’s corporate parent, by entities controlled 
or managed by Canada Pension Plan  Investment Board (“CPP Investments” ) and Global Infrastructure 
Partners ( “GIP,” and together with CPP Investments, “the Partners” ). The Partners have agreed to pay 
$67.00 per share for ALLETE’s outstanding common equity . Post -transaction, GIP will indirectly own 60 
percent of ALLETE, and CPP Investments will indirectly own 40 percent.  
 
In addition, Minnesota Power stated in the Petition that earlier this year GIP announced a transaction 
whereby BlackRock, Inc. (“BlackRock”), a large, publicly traded investment management firm  will 
acquire a 100%  interest in GIP (“the GIP/BlackRock Transaction”) . This transaction is currently awaiting 
the required last regulatory approvals and is anticipated to close during the third quarter of 2024 . 
 On July 23, 2024, the Commission issued a Notice of Comment Period (Notice), with the following topics open for comment:  
 
• Has Minnesota Power’s filing complied with all filing requirements under Minnesota Statute § 216B.50 and Minnesota Rules 7825.1700 and 7825.1800?  
• Should this matter be referred to the Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case proceeding and if so, what issues will require record development?  
• Are there other issues or concerns related to this matter?  
 
II. DEPARTMENT ANALYSIS  
A. HAS MINNESOTA POWER’S FILING COMPLIED WITH ALL FILING REQUIREMENTS UNDER MINNESOTA STATUTE § 216B.50 AND MINNESOTA RULES 7825.1700 AND 7825.1800?  
1. Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023)  
Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023) states, in part:  
 
No public utility shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or system in this state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000… …without first being authorized so to do by the commission. 
… If the commission finds that the proposed action is consistent with the 
public interest, it shall give its consent and approval by order in writing.  
 

Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
Analyst(s) assigned: Craig Addonizio  
Page 2 
 
 
 
 a. Minn. § Stat. 216B.50 (2023) as Applicable to the Acquisition 
The transaction for which Minnesota Power is seeking approval in the Petition  involves ALLETE, 
including Minnesota Power, selling and then merging itself as a system with “entities controlled or 
managed by”1 the Partners . Thus the proposed Acquisition is a transfer subject to the requirements of 
Minn. Stat. §  216B.50 (2023) . Through its Petition, Minnesota Power is seeking Commission 
authorization for the Acquisition, as required by the statute.  
 
b. GIP/BlackRock Transaction  
As noted above, simultaneous with GIP’s and CPP Investment’s proposed acquisition of ALLETE, 
BlackRock is  in the process of acquiring  “100 percent of the limited liability company interests of GIP ,” 
which will give BlackRock “an indirect interest in the ultimate general partner entities that control each 
of the GIP funds.”2  In their application to FERC for authorization of the GIP/BlackRock Transaction, GIP 
and BlackRock stated that after completion, “BlackRock will have an indirect controlling  interest in the 
GIM public utility subsidiaries”3 (emphasis added). The “GIM public utility subsidiaries” are the public 
utility companies indirectly owned and controlled by GIP and will include ALLETE and Minnesota Power 
if the Acquisition is approved and closed.  
 
The legal structures of GIP and BlackRock are complex, but the Department’s current understanding is that if both the Acquisition and the GIP/BlackRock Transaction receive all necessary approvals and 
close,  BlackRock, not GIP or CPP Investments, will have ultimate control over ALLETE and Minnesota 
Power.  
 If the GIP/BlackRock Transaction closes before the Acquisition, as expected according to the Petition, 
then the relevant transaction requiring Commission authorization will be BlackRock’s acquisition (via GIP) of ALLETE and Minnesota Power. Alternatively, if the Acquisition closes before the GIP/BlackRock Transaction , GIP will become a public utility as defined by Minn. Stat. § 216B.02, subd. 4 (2023)
4 and 
the GIP/BlackRock Transaction will then become an acquisition of a Minnesota public utility by 
BlackRock requiring  Commission authorization under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50  in a separate proceeding . 
Thus, regardless of the order in which the two transactions close, BlackRock’s potential ownership of 
ALLETE will require Commission authorization.   It is also possible that the GIP/BlackRock Transaction 
will not receive the necessary approvals and be terminated without closing.

2 Petition at 9.

furnishing at retail natural, manufactured, or mixed gas or electric service to or for the public or engaged in the productio n 
and retail sale thereof….”  Upon the close of the Acquisition, GIP will control Minnes ota Power’s system, and will therefore 
be a public utility.

Page 3 
 
 
 
 The Commission could opt to  wait until the GIP/BlackRock Transaction is fully resolved before 
consider ing BlackRock’s potential ownership of ALLETE . However,  doing so could result in a lengthy 
delay.  I n the interest of procedural efficiency, the Department recommends proceeding now as 
though BlackRock will become ALLETE’s owner. Therefore, the Department recommends that the 
Commission require Minnesota Power to supplement its Petition by November 1, 2024 with a filing 
requesting authorization and providing all information required by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 7825.1700 (2023) Minn. R. 7825.1800 (2023) regarding the GIP/BlackRock Transaction  and BlackRock’s 
potential ownership of ALLETE .  
 The Department is also concerned that BlackRock’s potential acquisition of GIP and ALLETE raises significant issues related to affiliated interests, which the Department addresses in greater detail below.  
 
2. Minn. R. 7825.1700 (2023)  
Minn. R. 7825.1700 (2023) requires that:  
 
A public utility, prior to entering into a transaction, shall petition for and receive from the commission by formal written order approval for such transaction. A petition for approval of capital structure (parts 7825.1000 to 7825.1500) shall be filed con currently with the petition for approval of 
transfer, merger, or consolidation if consideration for such a transaction is a security or securities as defined in part 7825.1000. The commission may 
require an independent valuation of the property involved in the 
transaction.  
 The Petition is the Company’s request for Commission approval of the Acquisition by formal written 
order, satisfying the first requirement of the Rule  with respect to the Partner’s proposed acquisition of 
ALLETE . However, as described above, Minnesota Power has not requested Commission authorization 
of the GIP/BlackRock Transaction .  
 Because ALLETE is being acquired, rather than acquiring property, it does not need to issue securities to exchange as consideration for property it is acquiring, or issue securities to raise cash to exchange as consideration . Therefore the second filing requirement of Minn. R. 7825.1700 (2023) does not apply  to 
the proposed Acquisition . In addition, Minnesota Power stated that it is not issuing securities at this 
time .  
 Finally, Minn. R. 7825. 1700 (2023) states that the Commission may require an independent valuation 
of the property involved in the transaction. Minnesota Power and the Partners have committed to not 
deploy “push down accounting” ( i.e., adjustment of Minnesota Power’s asset or liability values or 
books and records to reflect the purchase price ). As a result , for regulatory purposes, the book, or 
accounting , value of Minnesota Power will not be adjusted to reflect the purchase price  in any direct 
way. Therefo re, the Department concludes that there is no need for the Commission to require an 
Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
Analyst(s) assigned: Craig Addonizio  
Page 4 
 
 
 
 independent valuation of the property involved to determine of the purchase price is reasonable . 
However, if the Commission does wish to obtain an independent valuation, the Department will assist 
in any way it can.  
 Based on the above, the Department concludes that Minnesota Power’s Petition satisfies the filing requirements of Minn. R. 7825.1700 (2023)  with respect to the Acquisition, but not with respect to the 
GIP/BlackRock Transaction.  
 
3. Minn. R. 7825.1800 (2023)  
Minn. R. 7825.1800 (2023) provide a number of informational filing requirements.  The Department  
reviewed Minnesota Power’s Petition and concludes that it satisfies the filing requirements of Minn. R. 
7825.1800 (2023) with respect to the proposed Acquisition of ALLETE by GIP and CPP Investments , but 
not with respect to the GIP/BlackRock  Transaction . As described above, t he Department recommends 
that the Commission require Minnesota Power to supplement its Petition by November 1, 2024 with a 
filing providing  all necessary related information.  . 
 B. SHOULD THIS M ATTER BE REFERRED TO THE OFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGS FOR A 
CONTESTED CASE PROCEEDING AND IF SO, WHAT ISSUES WILL REQUIRE RECORD DEVELOPMENT?  
1. Contested Case Proceeding  
The Department recommends that the Commission refer this matter to the Office of Administrative 
Hearings  (“OAH”) for a contested case proceeding . Aspects of the proposed Acquisition raise novel and 
highly technical issues of fact and policy . The Acquisition, if approved, will result in ALLETE becoming a 
private company  and part of a much larger organization with a highly complex ownership structure . 
The Department anticipates u nderstanding that structure and the incentives it creates with respect to 
the long -term and day -to-day management of Minnesota Power  may require a significant amount of 
discovery, fact -finding, and record development  that is best facilitated by a contested case proceeding.  
 If the Commission refers this matter to the OAH, the Department also recommends that the 
Commission request the Administrative Law Judge’s Report by June  15, 2025. While there is no 
statutory time frame for this proceeding, the Department believes that a schedule based around this 
deadline reasonably balances the Company’s indicated desire to close the Acquisition in mid- 2025 with 
the need for adequate time for parti es to develop a full and robust record on this complex transaction.  
 
2. Issues Requiring Record Development  
The Department has started its review  of Minnesota Power’s  proposal by reviewing the  Petition , past 
property acquisition transactions in Minnesota, private equity acquisitions of public utilities in other jurisdictions, and certain related FERC proceedings . However, the Department’s review is still in its 
early stages, and the Department is not sure it has a complete list of specific issues to develop in this 
proceeding at this time . Therefore, t he Department recommends that the Commission define the 
Docket No. E015/PA-24-198

 issues requiring record development in this proceeding broadly . The Department recommends the 
Commission direct parties to develop a full record addressing, at a minimum, the following issues:  
 
• Are there any harms, costs, or risks to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the 
proposed transaction?  
• Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the 
proposed transaction?  
• Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction consistent with 
the public interest?  
• Are there regulatory requirements or commitments that could mitigate the harms, costs, or risks of the proposed transaction enough to render  it consistent with the public interest?  
• How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy Regulatory 
Commission, Wisconsin Public Service Commission, and/or other state, federal or foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration of the proposed transaction?    
 
C. ARE THERE OTHER ISSUES OR CONCERNS RELATED TO THIS MATTER?  
1. Affiliated Interests  
In its Petition, Minnesota Power addressed affiliated interests from three perspectives:  
 
• the impact of the Acquisition on existing affiliate contracts and arrangements within the ALLETE 
family of companies;  
• whether the Merger Agreement itself is an affiliated interest agreement; and  
• whether any unaffiliated interests with which ALLETE currently has existing contracts may become affiliated interests as a result of the Acquisition.
5 
 
With respect to existing contracts with currently unaffiliated interests that may become affiliated 
interests, the Company stated that “[a]fter reasonable diligence,” neither GIP nor CPP Investments 
have identified “any material contracts with ALLETE. ”6  However, the Company noted in footnote 31 of 
its Petition that ““CPP Investments” does not include its and its affiliates’ operating or portfolio 
companies, investment funds or vehicles, or investee companies.”7  It is not clear to the Department 
why the review of ALLETE’s contracts with CPP Investments would exclude contracts with these 
entities .  
 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.48, subd. 1(3) (2023)  states:  
 
every corporation five percent or more of whose voting securities is owned 
by any person or corporation owning five percent or more of the voting 
 
5 Petition at 37 -38. 
6 Petition at 38.  
7 Petition at 38 n. 31.  
Docket No. E015/PA-24-198 
Analyst(s) assigned: Craig Addonizio  
Page 6 
 
 
 
 securities of such public utility or by any person or corporation in any such 
chain of successive ownership of five percent or more of voting securities;  
 
Based on this language, the Department understands that any company of which CPP directly or indirectly owns a share of five percent or greater would become an affiliate of ALLETE of the Acquisition  were to be consummated.  
 Similarly, while Minnesota Power mentioned BlackRock’s ownership share of ALLETE, it did not discuss existing contracts it has that may become affiliated interest agreements if both the Acquisition and the GIP/BlackRock Transaction were to close . BlackRock is a multi- trillion investment manager that owns  
five percent or more of thousands  of companies . It is the Department’s understanding that if both 
transactions close, all of those companies would become affiliates of ALLETE and any contract or agreement ALLETE or Minnesota Power has now or in the future would become an affiliated interest agreement requiring  Commission approval.  
 
While the Department expects to further investigate affiliated interest issues as this Docket progresses, 
the Department re commends that the Commission require Minnesota Power to supplement its 
Petition by November 1, 2024 with a filing that comprehensively address  the potential affiliate status 
of the portfolio company holdings of the Partners and BlackRock.   
 
2. Request for Specialized Technical Professional Investigative Services  
As noted above, aspects of the proposed Acquisition, particularly the nature of ALLETE’s potential 
acquirers and the complex legal structure ALLETE will be a part of post -Acquisition, raise novel and 
highly technical issues of fact and policy . As such, t he Department requests that the Commission 
determine that it is necessary for the Department to obtain specialized technical professional investigative services to assist the Department in its review.  The Department makes this request 
pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.62, subd. 8 (2023) .  
 III. CONCLUSION  
Based on the Department’s  review and analysis of the Applicant’s petition, t he Department 
recommends that the Commission:  
 
1. Find with respect to the proposed acquisition of ALLETE, Inc. by entities controlled or managed 
by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board or Global Infrastructure Partners that  Minnesota Power’s Petition complies with all filing requirements under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023) and 
Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800 (2023);  
2. Require Minnesota Power to supplement its Petition in this proceeding by November 1, 2024, 
to include the following required information : 
a. a detailed explanation of whether the pending acquisition of certain interests in Global Infrastructure Partners by BlackRock, Inc. requires Commission authorization under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023), and if not, why not;

c. a discussion of affiliated interest issues that may arise between ALLETE and companies held directly or indirectly in the portfolios of Canada Pension Plan Investment Board or BlackRock, Inc.  
3. Refer this matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case and request the 
Administrative Law Judge’s Report by June  15, 2025 with the following issues to be developed

a. Are there any harms, costs, or risks to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the proposed transaction?

Re:  In the Matter the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada 
Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners   
Docket No. E015/PA -24-198 
 
 
Dear Mr. Seuffert,  
 
We, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local Union 31 (“Local 31”), 
respectfully submit our comments regarding Minnesota Power’s July 19, 2024 Petition for the  
Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure 
Partners . 
 
Local 31 represents approximately 438  members  employed by Minnesota Power, the 
majority of whom reside within the Minnesota Power service area as customers of the utility in 
either a wholesale or retail capacity.  Our interest in the outcome of proceeding is that of the 
continued employment of our Me mbers, the terms and conditions under which they work, the 
economic condition of the Company as it pertains to collective bargaining, the pressure on rates 
as ratepayers of the Company, and the local economic impacts to our communities as related to 
the Co mpany’s evolving mission .   
 Minnesota Power (“the Company”), Superior Water, Light & Power, and a 
representative of the Canada Pension Plan and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”) met and 
conferred with Local 31 regarding the contents of this pending docket  prior to filing .  Local 31 
has been assured by Company leadership and this filing that the new owners of the Company 

    will honor our existing Collective Bargaining Agreement, which is set to expire April 30, 2026.  
Presumably the next negotiation will be with Minnesota Power leadership under the authority 
of the new partners.  The impending purchase of GIP by BlackRock , Inc. leads the question as to 
who the controlling authority will be at that time.  We have been advised by the Company that  
like the operations of the Company will remain with its own existing senior leadership (and not 
the partners ’), the operations of GIP  will remain with GIP and not shift to  BlackRock.   Local 31 
will continue to work with the Company as these events transpire.  
 
Local 3 1 will continue to meet with the Company regarding whatever protections it may 
secure as the Company charts a new course, particularly around security, benefits and 
compensation, staffing,  and future opportunity for our membership  with an eye to the sustained 
reliability of its system.  Should the Commission decide that this Acquisition be referred to an 
Administrative Law Judge for a c ontested case hearing, Local 31 intends to file as an intervenor 
in that process.  
  
Dated:   August 19, 2024   Respectfully submitted,  
 
Kristin Renskers

In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  
 
  
PUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198  
INITIAL COMMENT  
 
 The Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”)1 submit this initial comment in response to the 
current notice of comment period (“Notice”) issued by the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 
(“Commission”  or “MPUC”) on July 23, 2024, in the above referenced docket.2 Simultaneously , 
LPI has  filed a Petition to Intervene .  
I.  INTRODUCTION/BACKGROUND  
On July 19, 2024, ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power (“ALLETE”) filed its petition for 
Commission approval of the acquisition of ALLETE  (“Petition”)  by Canada Pension Plan 
Investment (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”)  (collectively, 
“Partners”)  (“Proposed Transaction”) .3   The Proposed Transaction raises numerous novel legal
