defined, references to ‘ALLETE’ indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including Minnesota Power and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries.  ‘The Company’ is a more gener al reference to ALLETE, 
Inc d/b/a Minnesota Power.”  Petition, at 1, fn. 1.  Given that the Proposed Transaction would result in the 
acquisition of all shares of ALLETE, it is not clear why or how there would be any difference in benefit to ALLETE or the Company as a result of the Proposed Transaction.  In any event, the ratepayers of ALLETE/the 
Company, and how their interests are impacted, is of critical concern and should be addressed in a contested case 
process.  
 
2 questions, including whether Minnesota Power becoming a privately held entity is consistent with 
the public interest . The Petition states that the primary goal of the Proposed Transaction is to 
“enable Minnesota Power to obtain the significant additional capital it needs to continue and 
expand its investment in clean energy technology and systems … and to further its comm itment to 
provide safe, reliable, and affordable energy to its customers.”4 Based on its initial review of the 
Petition, LPI does not have sufficient information to verify the accuracy ALLETE’s assertion s. 
The Notice poses three questions for comment: (1) whether Minnesota Power has complied 
with all filing requirements under Minnesota Statute § 216B.50 and Minnesota Rules 7825.1700 
and 7825.1800;  (2) whether the matter should be referred to the Office of Administrative Hearings 
(“OAH”) for contest ed case and if so, what issue s require record development ; and (3) whether 
other issues or concerns exist relating to this matter.   LPI submits this initial comment to 
(i) recommend contested case treatment before the OAH; and (ii) during  that contested case 
process, request further record development on various issues, including the proper public interest 
standard of review applicable to the Proposed Transaction.  
II.  ANALYSIS  
  In its Petition, ALLETE proposes the Commission employ an interpretation of the public 
interest standard of review where “consistent with the public interest”5 requires weighing the 
potential detriments and benefits of a transaction ; if the detriments do not outweigh the benefits, 
the Commission must  find the transaction “compatible” with the public interest.6  As a threshold 
matter, LPI questions ALLETE’s framing of the standard of review and its summary of applicable precedent, especially here, where the Commission and stakeholders are being asked to address a 
transaction under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 that results in an investor -owned utility being taken 
private.  CPP  Investment s’ 2024 Annual Report states it actively seeks to “maximize returns” as a 
guiding mandate.
7 The Petition itself concedes that “private infrastructure investors such as the 
Partners seek a reasonable return on their investments and a reasonable opportunity to earn that 
 
4  Petition at 2.  
5  Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  
6  Petition at 13.  
7  Annual Report 2024, C ANADA PENSION PLAN INVESTMENTS  (2024), https://www.cppinvestments.com/wp -
content/uploads/2024/07/CPP -Investments -F2024 -Annual -Report.pdf .  
3 return.”8 Furthermore, the Petition states that ALLETE’s updated capital program includes over 
$4.3 billion in investments over the next five years – a roughly $1 billion increase from the 
ALLETE investor presentation just one short year before .9  The juxtaposition of ALLETE’s 
investment announcements with the Petition, continued focus on investment growth, and proposed 
private oversight of future investment plans concerns LPI, the combination of which will 
undoubtedly exacerbate  uncompetitive electric rates for Minnesota Power’s customers, 
particularly the Large Power and Large Light & Power customer classes . Vague statements about 
CPP Investments ’ and GIP’s commitment to customers and serving customer needs do little to 
quell concerns regarding the fundamental priorities of CPP  Investments  and GIP: to invest, and 
recoup a rate of return on those investments.10  Without more information  about the Proposed 
Transaction ’s potential effects on Minnesota Power customers , LPI cannot opine  as to whether the 
standard of review proposed by ALLETE  complies with all applicable  Minnesota filing  
requirements  (per question two of the Notice) .  LPI respectfully asserts that  no party can fully 
assess the merits of the Petition or t he suitability of the proposed public interest standard of review  
without further record development . This issue represents a material issue of fact best addressed 
in a contested case setting where parties can fully develop the record.   
A. The Commission Should Refer this Matter to the OAH for Contested Case Treatment  
The Commission has stated that “ [i]f a proceeding involves contested material facts and 
there is a right to a hearing under statute or rule  … the commission shall  refer the matter to the 
Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case proceeding.”11  The Petition contains a 
number of untested assertions, including that “the acquisition is in the best interests of the

in the 2022 investor presentation (link here, slide 4).  
10  E.g., Petition at 14 (stating only that ALLETE retains its obligation to customers to provide safe, reliable, and 
affordable service).  
11  Minn. R. 7829.1000 (emphasis added).  
4 Company,[12] its stakeholders, and the public.”13  Notably absent from this assertion, and the 
Petition generally,  is any specific benefit to Minnesota Power’s ratepayers.  Based on the Petition, 
and the record developed to date, LPI respectfully asserts that the only path forward for reviewing 
the Petition that balances all stakeholder interests is a contested case p roceeding, with record 
development as outlined below.  ALLETE agrees,14 providing further support for contested case 
treatment.  
B. Record Development and Clarification on the Appropriate Standard of Review  is 
Critical in Addressing Ratepayer Benefits (If Any) from the Proposed Transaction  
 In relevant part, Minnesota Statute § 216B.50 requires Commission authorization for any 
public utility to “ sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or system in this state 
for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000, or merge or consolidate with another public utility or transmission company operating in this state .”
 15 Further, i f the C ommission finds the proposed 
action consistent with the public interest, § 216B.50 requires  “it shall give its consent and approval 
….”16  That this provision of Minnesota law governs review of the Petition is  not at issue.  The 
interpretation of this provision, and evidence required for ALLETE to satisfy its burden of proof, will be an issue and should be subject to additional record development in a contested case process.  
 For example, it appears ALLETE’s Petition inaccurately interprets and applies 
Commission guidance from  two MPUC cases , which ALLETE claims support s the proposition 
that “consistent with the public interest” merely requires a showing that the detriments of a transaction do not outweigh its  benefits to ratepayers . ALLETE overlooks other precedent and 
fails to acknowledge that both cases  involve  the weighing of much more significant  ratepayer 
benefits than those in the Proposed Transaction.  For example, hist orical Commission precedent  
approving acquisitions involve d acquisitions  that: lowered energy costs for utility customers and

Transaction.  In any event, the ratepayers of ALLETE/the Company, and how their interests are impacted, is of 
critical concern and should be addressed in a contested case process.  
13    Petition  at 2. 
14    Petition at 23  (noting that referral “offers the benefits of a robust, defined, and efficient process for intervention

15  Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.

5 improved efficiencies;17 enhanced reliability and diversity of gas supply, increased economies of 
scale, improved financing capabilities due to size,18 and included stipulations to provide additional 
reporting information;19 and resulted in tangible ratepayer benefits from rate reductions and price 
freezes.20  The Petition relies on a portion of this MPUC precedent to allege its Proposed 
Transaction complies with public interest requirements – but the Proposed Transaction does not 
purport to yield any rate reductions for ratepayers. The Petition only reports the  potential consumer 
benefits of supporting Minnesota Power’s “ongoing sustainability efforts” and achieving State 
policy goals to transition to clean energy. T he true potential impacts to ratepayers, especially as it 
relates to cost  and bill impacts , remain entirely unknown.21  These allegations are insufficient to 
demonstrate the Proposed Transaction meets  public interest  requirements —the allegations appear 
premised on the unsupported assertion that ALLETE’s decarbonization efforts can occur at any 
cost. 
 To demonstrate consistency with the public interest, precedent from Minnesota and other 
jurisdictions22 supports a higher standard of review and greater ratepayer benefits than provided 
for in the Petition .  For example, the Commission found a § 216B.50 merger consistent with  the 
public interest whe re it produced: “significant ratepayer benefits and protections (rate decrease and 
rate freeze),” “reasonable assurance that ratepayers will be adequately protected from corporate 
structure changes resulting from the proposed merger,” low likelihood of adverse impacts t o 
wholesale competition, adequate mitigation of impacts to retail competition (i.e., “through stipulations related to generation cost disclosure, distributed generation aggregation, and a 
customer buyback tariff”), as well as other assurances related to new interconnecting technologies,

22  The North Carolina Utilities Commission assesses consistency with the public interest under a higher standard

was “justified by public convenience and necessity” because there were significant savings and commitments to

ratepayers. In re Duke Energy Corp ., 232 N.C. App. 573 (Mar. 4, 2014).  
6 studies address ing environmental concerns, and increased contributions to low -income assistance 
programs.23  By contrast, the Petition states only that it is “not seeking to make changes” to how 
Minnesota Power operates  (despi te the potential for reality to diverge from ALLETE’s intentions ) 
and that the Proposed Transaction will “produce significant benefits by allowing ALLETE to 
partner with global leaders in the infrastructure space … to provide the Company with the capital 
necessary to continue … transitioning to a cleaner future….”24 The Petition demonstrates that the 
primary benefits resulting from the Proposed Transaction belong to ALLETE and its investment partners – it does not demonstrate any ratepayer benefits.  The Petition does not, for example, 
contain any substantive analysis demonstrating that ALLETE’s decarbonization efforts will be more cost -effective under new ownership.  In fact, the opposite could be true.  I t is possible for the 
Proposed Transaction to result in expedited decarbonization efforts for the benefit of new ownership, driving up costs for ratepayers and stripping them of the protections that come with a 
publicly owned utility, in which case t he touted benefits to ALL ETE do not outweigh the potential 
harms to ratepayers.   The Commission can, and should, require additional record development on 
these topics in a contested case process.   
C. Record Development is Also Necessary to Incorporate Other Related Proceedings  
 In conjunction with the Petition, ALLETE also submitted filings for approval before the 
Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (“FERC”)
25 and the Wisconsin Public Service 
Commission.26  LPI also notes that  the FERC issued a Notice of Inquiry on December 19, 2023 ,27 
to examine the market influence of powerful investment managers, assessing  FERC’s blanket 
authorization under Federal Power Act § 203(a)(2) (under which ALLETE filed its parallel 
application at FERC),28 and whether related policies should account for an investment company’s 
size.  Further, FERC sought comment  on factors it should consider when evaluating  an investment

203 of the Federal Power Act and Requests for Shortened Comment Period, Expedited Action and Limited 
Waivers, Docket No. EC24- 105-000 (Jul. 19, 2024).  LPI intends to participate in this proceeding.

in the Alternative, for Approvals of a Holding Company Takeover , Verified Petition, PSCW Docket No. 5820-
DR-100 (Jul. 19, 2024).

7 company’s control over public utilities. FERC’s Notice of Inquiry highlights a concern present in 
the instant matter –  that private equity firms can invest with short -term profit interests that are 
incongruous with the long- term needs and goals of public utilities. T he dynamic and developing 
nature of the investment landscape , as well as the identity  of the Partners , necessitate additional 
scrutiny in the instant matter . LPI respectfully  urges the Commission to account for this emerging 
issue at FERC, as well as in the other dockets pertaining to the Proposed Transaction, in 
determining which public interest standard of review to apply in its  analysis.  
D. LPI Recommended Issues for Contested Case Development  
 With this commentary in mind, LPI has coordinated with other stakeholders, including the 
Minnesota Department of Commerce -Division of Energy Resources, Minnesota Office of the 
Attorney General -Residential Utilities Division, and Citizens Utilities Board, on how to best 
develop a record on whether the Proposed Transaction is consistent with the public interest.  LPI respectfully requests contested case treatment of t he following issues , which LPI understands  these  
other parties also support : 
1. Are there any harms , costs, or risks to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from 
the P roposed T ransaction?   
2. Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the 
Proposed T ransaction?    
3. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, i s the proposed transaction consistent 
with the public interest?    
4. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments sufficient to mitigate the harms, costs, 
or risks of the proposed transaction to render it consistent with the public interest?  
5. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Wisconsin Public Service Commission, and/or other state, federal or foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration of the proposed transaction?    
 
III. CONCLUSION 
 LPI appreciates the opportunity to provide this initial comment on the Petition. LPI believes a 
contested case proceeding is the  appropriate forum to examine the factual assertions within the 
Petition and  agrees with the Petition’s statements  supporting referral of this matter to the OAH . 
LPI looks forward to continuing thoughtful examination of those issues in a contested case setting.

PUC Docket No. E015/ PA-24-198  
PETITION TO INTERVENE  
 
I. INTRODUCTION 
The following companies request permission to intervene in this matter collectively as a 
party known as the Large Power Intervenors (“LPI”): Blandin Paper Company; Boise Paper, a 
Packaging Corporation of America company, formerly known as Boise, Inc.; Cleveland -Cliffs 
Minorca Mine Inc.; Enbridge Energy, Limited Partnership; Gerdau Ameristeel US Inc.; Hibbing Taconite Company; Sappi Cloquet, LLC; USG Interiors, Inc.; United States Steel Corporation 
(Keetac and Minntac Mines); and United Taconite, LLC. 
II. ANALYSIS  
 For a non- governmental agency, the Minnesota Rules require a petition to intervene to set 
forth (1) the manner in which the petitioner’s legal rights, duties, or privileges may be impacted 
by the contested case; (2) how the petitioner may be directly impa cted by the outcome; and (3) the 
grounds and purposes for which intervention is sought.1  Once this showing is made, the 
intervention shall be allowed unless the petitioner’s interest is adequately represented by one or 
more parties participating in the case.2  The Minnesota Practice series provides additional detail 
concerning a petition to intervene .  “The focus of a decision regarding intervention should be on 
the protection of the original parties from a drastic change in direction of the administrative 
 
1  Minn. R. 1400.6200, subd. 1.  
2  Minn. R. 1400.6200, subd. 3.  
 
2 proceeding and against undue delay and cost to them.”3  Indeed, of the factors listed by the 
Minnesota Practice series, three relate to the impact the intervention may have on the contested 
case process.  The five factors that should be consider ed are: (1) the extent to which the contested 
proceedings have progressed; (2) whether the present parties will adequately represent the 
petitioner’s interests; (3) whether the petitioner will introduce new issues; (4) whether the 
intervention will cause undue delay; and (5) whether the petitioner will be injured in fact by the 
final decision.4  While the weighing of these factors is left with the decisionmaker , “it is an abuse 
of discretion to deny intervention to one whose interest is substantial, who may be adversely 
affected, and whose interests are not adequately represented by existing parties.”5  LPI’s petition 
to intervene should be granted because its interests are substantial, it will be directly impacted by the decision in this case, no other party will be representing its unique interests, and granting 
intervention will not unfairly impact the  other parties or cause undue delay at this early stage in 
the proceeding. 
Cleveland -Cliffs Minorca Mine Inc., Hibbing Taconite Company, United States Steel 
Corporation’s Keetac and Minntac Mines, and United Taconite, LLC are all taconite mining and 
beneficiation facilities located on the Mesabi Iron Range in St. Louis County, Mi nnesota.  Blandin 
Paper Company, Boise Paper, and Sappi Cloquet, LLC all operate paper and pulp mills and associated facilities that are located at Grand Rapids, International Falls, and Cloquet, Minnesota, 
respectively.  Enbridge Energy operates the Unite d States portion of an operationally integrated 
pipeline system spanning 3,300 miles across North America to connect producers and shippers of 
crude petroleum and natural gas liquids in the United States and western Canada with markets in 
the United States  and eastern Canada, which pipeline spans Minnesota and Minnesota Power’s 
service territory.  USG Interiors, Inc. operates a ceiling tile manufacturing facility in Cloquet, 
Minnesota.  Gerdau Ameristeel US Inc. operates a facility in Duluth, Minnesota that  produces steel 
grinding balls for application in the mineral processing and mining industries.     
Each of these entities is currently a member of either the Large Power Class or Large Light 
& Power Class on the Minnesota Power system.  Collectively, LPI consumes roughly two- thirds 
 
3  21 William J. Keppel, Minnesota Practice, Administrative Practice &  Procedure § 9.16.4, Westlaw ( 2d ed., 
database updated Oct. 2021).  
4  Id. 
5  Id.  
 
3 of the power that Minnesota Power delivers at retail in Minnesota and employs many residential 
ratepayers of Minnesota Power.  For all these industrial customers, the cost of energy is a 
significant cost component of operations.  
In its petition for a cquisition, ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power  seeks approval for the 
Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global Infrastructure Partners 
(“GIP”)  to acquire ALLETE , to allow Minnesota Power to secure additional capital to continue its 
investments in clean energy technology and systems .6 Given the critical role that Minnesota 
Power’s power supply and electric energy costs play in LPI members’ operations, ALLETE’s 
acquisition will substantially impact the interests of LPI member organizations .  LPI therefore has 
a substantial interest in the outcome of this case and will be directly impacted by any decision.  
Furthermore,  as large industrial consumers of electric energy, LPI’s interests in this proceeding 
are unique and will not be adequately addressed or protected by other intervenors.  To be sure, LPI’s participation in this matter will not disadvantage or burden any other party.  LPI intends to 
participate  as an interested party in this docket and consistent ly participa tes in various other 
Minnesota Power dockets.  As such, this petition should not surprise any party or cause undue 
delay.  Intervention is thus warranted under Rule 1400.6200 of the Minnesota Administrative 
Rules.  Therefore, LPI request s that its petition be granted.   
III. CONCLUSION  
LPI’s substantial interests can only be adequately represented through separate 
intervention.  Granting LPI’s request for intervention will not adversely impact these proceedings.  
Indeed, LPI hopes its participation in this matter will assist all parties in the review of Minnesota 
Power’s petition for a cquisition of ALLETE by CPP Investments  and GIP.  Therefore, LPI 
respectfully requests its petition to intervene be granted.

1 STATE OF MINNESOTA  
PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
   Katie Sieben    Chair  
   Hwikwon Ham    Commissioner  
Valerie Means    Commissioner  
   Joseph Sullivan    Commissioner  
   John Tuma    Commissioner  
 
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for 
the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  Docket No. E- 015/PA -24-198 
 
Comments of the Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota  
The Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota (“CUB”) respectfully submits these Initial  Comments in 
response to the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission’s (“Commission”) Notice of Comment  Period 
issued  on July 23 , 202 4.1 The Notice requests comments on the following topics, as they relate to 
Minnesota Power’s June 19, 2024 petition (the “Petition”) seeking approval of a proposed acquisition 
involving ALLETE, Inc., the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board , and Global Infrastructure Partners  
(the “Proposed Transaction”) : 
 
• Has Minnesota Power’s filing complied with all filing requirements under Minnesota Statute § 
216B.50 and Minnesota Rules 7825.1700 and 7825.1800?  
 
• Should this matter be referred to the Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case 
proceeding and if so, what issues will require record development?  
 
• Are there other issues or concerns related to this matter?  
 
In summary, we recommend that the Commission: 1) refer this matter to the OAH for  a contested 
case proceeding  and 2 ) grant CUB’s petition to intervene as a party in the contested case proceeding.  
 
I. ANALYSIS  
 
At the outset, we want to thank The Company’s regulatory staff for their efforts to meet with us, share 
information, and answer questions related to the Proposed Transaction . While our comments here 
 
1 In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
and Global Infrastructure Partners , Notice of  Comment Period, Docket  No. E-15/PA -24-198 ( July 23, 2024)  (“Commission 
Notice”)  
 
2 do not address in depth the substance of the Company’s Petition, we appreciate the Company’s 
willingness to listen  and respond  to early questions and concerns we have raised about it. We look 
forward to offering additional analysis and recommendations on the substantive aspects of the 
Proposed Transaction  as this regulatory process moves forward.  
 
A. Though  the Petition appears to meet minimum procedural requirements, 
additional evidence should be considered to determine whether the Proposed 
Transaction is consistent with the public interest. 
 
The Petition discusses several applicable Minnesota filing requirements , focusing in particular on 
Minn. Stat.  § 216B.50, Minn. R. 7825.1 700, and Minn. R. 7825.18 00.  
 
Minnesota Statute § 216B.50  provides that:  
 
No public utility shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or system in 
this state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000, or merge or consolidate with 
another public utility or transmission company operating in this st ate, without first being 
authorized so to do by the commission. Upon the filing of an application for the approval and consent of the commission, the commission shall investigate, with or without public hearing. 
The commission shall hold a public hearing, upon such notice as the commission may require. 
If the commission finds that the proposed action is consistent with the public interest, it shall 
give its consent and approval by order in writing. In reaching its determination, the 
commission shall take into consideration the reasonable value of the property, plant, or 
securities to be acquired or disposed of, or merged and consolidated.  
 Minnesota Rule 7825.1700 provides:  
 
A public utility, prior to entering into a transaction, shall petition for and receive from the 
commission by formal written order approval for such transaction. A petition for approval of 
capital structure (parts  7825.1000  to 7825.1500 ) shall be filed concurrently with the petition 
for approval of transfer, merger, or consolidation if consideration for such a transaction is a security or securities as defined in part  7825.1000 . The commission may require an 
independent valuation of the property involved in  the transaction.  
 
Minnesota Rule 7825.1800 (B) establishes more detailed requirements for what must be included in 
the Company’s P etition. Among those requirements, the Petition must include: “all information, for 
each public utility, as required in parts  7825.1400  and 7825.1500 .” Minn. Rule 7825.1400 then outlines 
requirements for what the Commission must include regarding its new proposed capital structure . 
Minn. Rule 7825.1500  imposes additional filing requirements that would apply if the Company were 
to register a securities offering with the federal Securities and Exchange Commission.  
 
 
3 The Company notes  "it is not issuing securities nor entering into new affiliate interest agreements at 
this time, and therefore Minn. Stat. §§  216B.48  and 216B.49  and the associated Rules, do not apply 
except as cross -referenced by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 or Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800."  For these 
reasons , the Company  exclude s certain information that would otherwise be required by 7825.1400 . 
For example, the Company does not include an opinion of counsel (which is required by Minn. R. 
7825.1400, Subp. I) because “ALLETE is not issuing securities in conjunction with the Acquisition.” 2 
 The Petition appears to include the  minimum information required (or an explanation for why such 
information is not required under the  current  circumstances). We appreciate, however, that the 
Company does not “foreclose the possibility” of needing to seek separate, additional approvals in the 
future.
3 We also think additional record development will be needed on some fundamental questions 
not fully addressed in the Petition, including  (without limitation) : 
 
1) How will BlackRock’s pending acquisition of GIP affect the Proposed Transaction and the 
Commission’s ability to determine whether it is consistent with  the public interest?  
 
2) If a purported benefit of the Proposed Transaction is improved access to capital, how does 
that improved access to capital affect rates and ratepayers?  
 We believe that these, and other, questions will be best addressed in a contested case proceeding.  
 
B. The Commission should refer this matter to the OAH for a contested case 
proceeding . 
 
Ultimately, determining whether the Proposed Transaction is  “consistent with  the public interest”  will 
require additional legal and factual analyses. From our perspective, that analysis should begin with an 
examination of what it means for the Proposed Transaction to be “consistent with the public interest.” 
The Petition cites a 1990 Order in noting “ the Commission has determined that this standard  does not 
require an affirmative finding of public benefit but requires only a finding that the  transaction is 
compatible with the public interest. ”
4 However, energy policy and utility service have changed 
considerably in the past 34 years. The Commission should reexamine the applicable legal standard 
with a fresh perspective that accounts for recent public policy developments promoting affordability, 
equity, and greenhouse gas emissions reduction.  
 
CUB is also concerned about  the inherent conflict of interest that arises between ratepayers wanting 
to pay as little as possible for safe and reliable electric service and private equity investors wanting to 
maximize their return on investment. The Proposed Transaction would consolidate ownership and 
decision- making  authority amongst a smaller number of highly sophisticated shareholders who may 
 
2 Petition at 30.  
3 Petition at 26.  
4 Petition at 12  
 
4 have considerable interest and ability to shape Minnesota Power’s rates, service model, and strategic 
vision. It is imperative for stakeholders and the Commission to better understand both the 
opportunities and risks that arise under this new corporate and financial structure in order to 
determine whether it is consistent with the public interest.  In our view, the Commission should not 
approve the Proposed Transaction unless the record supports a finding that the net benefits of the Proposed Transaction (bo th to the Company and ratepayers) are likely to outweigh any net harm.  
 CUB  has spoken to  other stakeholders, including the Minnesota Department of Commerce -Division 
of Energy Resources, Minnesota Office of the Attorney General -Residential Utilities Division, and Large 
Power Intervenors , on how to best develop such a record.   CUB  proposes the following questions for 
further development in a contested case.  
 
1. Are there any harms,  costs,  or risks to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the 
Proposed Transaction?    
 
2. Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from the 
Proposed Transaction?    
 
3. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction consistent with 
the public interest?    
 
4. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments  sufficient to mitigate  the harms, costs, or 
risks of the proposed transaction to render it consistent with the public interest?  
5. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Wisconsin Public Service Commission, and/or other state, federal or foreign 
government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration of the proposed transaction?     
 
C. CUB respectfully requests  that the Commission grant CUB intervenor status . 
 
If the Commission refers this matter to the OAH, CUB intends to intervene in the contested case 
proceeding as a party. We respectfully request that the Commission approve CUB’s intervention in 
the contested case pursuant to  Minn. Rules 7829.0800 and 7829.2400, subpart 6 . 
 As the Commission knows, CUB regularly intervenes in Commission dockets and contested case 
proceedings to advocate for the interests of residential rate payers. For example , CUB has intervened 
as a party in the following recent  contested case proceedings:  
 
● In the Matter of the Application of Northern States Power Company for Authority to  Increase Rates 
for Natural Gas Service in Minnesota (Docket No. G -002/GR -23-413) 
 
5 ● In the Matter of the Application of Minnesota Energy Resources Corporation for Authority to Increase 
Rates for Natural Gas Utility Service In Minnesota (Docket No. G -011/GR -22-504)  
● In the Matter of the Application of Northern States Power Company d/b/a Xcel  Energy for Authority 
to Increase Rates for Electric Utility Service in Minnesota (Docket No. E002/GR -21-630)  
● In the Matter of the Application of Minnesota Power for Authority to Increase Rates  (Docket No. 
E015/GR -21-335)  
● In the Matter of the Petitions for Recovery of Certain Gas Costs  (Docket Nos. G -008/M -21-138, 
G004/M -21-235, G -002/CI -21-610, G -011/CI -21-611)  
 
As a consumer advocate, CUB also has an interest in the outcome of this proceeding. The proposed 
acquisition has the potential to impact ratepayers’ interests in numerous ways. In particular, a new 
corporate, financial, and governance structure at ALLETE and its family of companies could create 
pressure or incentive for Minnesota Power to  raise rates, adjust its low- income and other customer 
programs, and otherwise change the nature and costs of its services. As a consumer advocate that 
regularly engages wi th Minnesota Power ratepayers, CUB is well -suited to raise  questions, introduce 
evidence, and make recommendations designed to help protect ratepayers’ interests. For these 
reasons, we respectfully request that the Commission approve CUB’s intervention to participate with 
full party status in the contested case proceedings  by noting its approval in an order referring this 
matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings.  
 
II. CONCLUSION  
 
In summary, we recommend that the Commission: 1) refer this matter to the OAH for  a contested 
case proceeding and 2 ) grant CUB’s petition to intervene as a party in the contested case proceeding.  
 
Thank you for considering our comments.  
 Sincerely,         August  19, 2024

and/or Global Infrastructure Partners .

intervention requests are covered by the OAH procedures, pursuant to Minn.  Rules, part

MPUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198
Initial Filing – Petition  for Approval  
Dear Mr. Seuffert:  
ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power ( the “Company” ) hereby respectfully submit s, via 
electronic filing, its Petition  to the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission ( the “Commission ”) for 
an order approving an acquisition of the Company  by entities under the control or managemen t of 
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”)  and/or Global Infrastructure Partners  
(“GIP”)  (together , the “Partners” ). 
As discussed in this Petition, the  Company anticipates there will be additional questions 
regarding this Petition and the information contained within it, as well as with respect to matters 
related to the transaction.  The Company understands the Commission may wish to refer the matter 
to an Administrative Law Judge, and supports that procedural path.  The Company provides 
additional discussion of potential procedural processes within Section III.C  of the Petition, and 
looks forward to further dialogue on this matter with the Commission and o ther stakeholders.  
If you have any questions regarding this filing, please contact me at (218) 723 -3963 or 
dmoeller@allete.com . 
Yours truly,  
David R. Moeller  
Senior Regulatory  Counsel

controlled or managed by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board  (“CPP Investments”)  or 
Global Infrastructure Partners (“GIP,” and together  with CPP Investments , the “Partners”) will 
acquire  ALLET E (the “Acquisition ”), as explained in further detail in the petition.  Through the  
Acquisi tion, ALLETE  will transition to a private company  wholly -owned by a new Partner -created 
company known as Alloy Parent LLC , providing ALLETE with improved access to capital  and 
Partner resources that can  support ALLETE’s investment in the clean energy transition  while 
continuing  the safe, reliable,  and affordable electric service Minnesota Power’s customers expect . 
While the  Acquisition  will change the ownership of  ALLETE , many things  will not change , 
including: (1)  Minnesota Power ’s operations, strateg y, and values ; (2) the Commission’s authority 
over Minnesota Power and its Minnesota operations;  (3) Minnesota Power’s commitments to the 
customers and communities it has served for over a century ; and (4)  the transparency to which the 
Commission is accust omed in its regulation of Minnesota Power . Moreover, t he Acquisition  is not 
expected to impact  retail or municipal rates for utility customers  nor materially  affect other utility  
matters pending before  the Commission .

I. INTRODUCTION  
Pursuant to  Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 , Minn. R. 7825.1800 , and other provisions of the 
Minnesota Rules , ALLETE, Inc.  d/b/a Minnesota Power1 submits this Petition for Approval 
(“Petition”) to the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission (the “Commission”)  to provide 
information and seek Commission approval of  a transaction , as described in more detail below, 
through which  entities controlled or managed by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
(collectively “CPP Investments”)  and/or Global Infrastructure Par tners ( collectively “GIP”)  
(together, the “Partners”) will, through a new Partner -created  entity  known as Alloy Parent LLC 
(“Parent”) ,2 acquire  all shares of ALLETE  and hold all interest in the enterprise going forward (the 
 
1 As the Commission is aware, Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc.  Throughout this 
Petition, we use “Minnesota Power” to refer to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota.  Unless otherwise 
specifically defined, references t o “ALLETE” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including 
Minnesota Power and all regulated and non -regulated subsidiaries.  “The Company” is a more general reference to 
ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.   
2 Post-transaction, Parent will b e the 100  percent owner of ALLETE, and Parent will be owned 40  percent by a wholly 
owned subsidiary of CPP Investments and 60  percent by investment entities managed and controlled by GIP affiliates, 
all as detailed in Sections II.B.2 and II.C  of this Petit ion and in Attachments A and  B hereto.  
 
2 “Acquisition ”). The terms of th is Acquisition are set forth in the Agreement and Plan of Merger 
dated May 5, 2024  (the “Merger Agreement ”), provided as Attachment B to this Petition.  
Minnesota Power submits this Petition because the Acquisition is in the best interests of 
the Company, its stakeholders, and the public . The primary goal of  transitioning to  a private 
company is to enable Minnesota Power to obtain the significant additiona l capital it needs to 
continue and expand its investment in clean energy technology and systems, including changing  
transmission and generation needs, and  to further its commitment to provide  safe, reliable, and  
affordable  energy to  its customers.  Further,  the Company   has chosen to enter this transaction with 
Partners who are premier, well -resourced infrastructure investors at a global scale with  an 
extensive base of assets and relationships that the Company can leverage where applicable, to the 
benefit of  consumers.  The Partners also bring deep industry expertise with respect to utility and 
energy infrastructure and renewables.  As described further in this Petition, the Partners are aligned 
with the Company’s vision of continuing to advance the State of Mi nnesota’s  clean energy goals 
and the operations, relationships, and strong Minnesota presence of the Minnesota Power utility.  
The Acquisition is expected to benefit customers by offering ALLETE better alternatives to the 
volatility and inflexible demands of the capital marketplace when financing is needed, because the 
Company  will have Partners who are familiar with the energy industry and aligned  with Minnesota 
Power’s values that have served cu stomers effectively for more than 100 years.  
Overall, the Acquisition focuses on supporting the Company’s necessary future 
investments.  No changes to Minnesota Power’s costs or rates, cost structures, operations, or long -
term plans are requested or expecte d in connection with the Acquisition.  Before and after the  
Acquisition , ALLETE will  continue to exist as a  corporate entity , owning and operating  Minnesota 
Power  and its other  utility and non -utility businesses . Further, no changes to the manner in which  
 
3 the Company provides electric service to its retail and wholesale customers,  to its relationship with 
the people and communities of Minnesota  or with the Commission , or to customer  costs of  utility 
service  are anticipated as a result of the  Acquisition.  Further, ALLETE will continue to honor and 
maintain all existing obligations to its employees and existing labor and employment contracts.  
The Acquisition  also will have no impact on  other Minnesota Power matters pending before  the 
Commission, including th e Company’s pending rate case, existing planning and  permitting 
dockets, or  other current regulatory obligations.  Finally, no transaction or other costs  associated 
with the Acquisition will be assigned to Minnesota Power customers.  
In these ways, the Acqu isition will support continuation of the ALLETE family of 
companies in its current form.  ALLETE and the Partners are particularly focused on continuation 
of management and employee staffing  because this will support Minnesota Power’s continuation 
of delive ring safe , reliable, and affordable electric service.  Moreover, Minnesota Power  will 
continue to operate  and be regulated by the Commission as it always has been, which provides 
further assurance that the Commission will be able to continue to look out for  the interests of 
customers in Minnesota as it always has done.  In these ways, the Acquisition will support 
continuation of the ALLETE family of companies in its current form.   
Accordingly,  Minnesota Power  requests that the  Commission  approve the  Acquisition , as 
described  in further detail in this  Petition  and its Attachments . 
II. INTRODUCTION  OF PARTIES  AND THE TRANSACTION  
A. ALLETE , Inc.  
ALLETE  is a reliable provider of competitively priced energy  and invests in transmission 
infrastructure and other en ergy-centric businesses  with a national footprint.  Headquartered in 
Duluth, Minnesota, ALLETE  is a Minnesota corporation that  is currently publicly traded on the 
New York Stock Exchange.   
 
4 The entity now known as ALLETE was incorporated under the laws of th e State of 
Minnesota on January 25, 1906, as the Duluth -Edison Electric Company.3 In 1923, the Duluth -
Edison Electric Company changed its name to Minnesota Power & Light Company.4 Pursuant to 
Restated Articles of Incorporation filed with the Minnesota Secretary of State on May 12, 1998, 
Minnesota Power & Light Company became Minnesota Power, Inc.5 A few years later (effective 
May 8, 2001), Minnesota Power, Inc. changed its name to ALLETE, Inc.  d/b/a Minnesota Power.6 
The stock of ALLETE is currently traded on the New York Stock Exchange.  As of March 31, 
2024, approximately 51 percent of ALLETE’s outstanding shares are owned by 18 investors, with 
BlackRock Fund Advisors (a subsidiar y of BlackRock Inc.  (“BlackRock”)) owning approximately 
11.6 percent of common stock , with another approximately 2 percent owned by other BlackRock 
subsidiaries,  and The Vanguard Group, Inc. holding approximately 11.5 percent.7  
ALLETE’s largest business unit is its regulated Minnesota electric utility, Minnesota 
Power , which generates, transmits, and distributes electric energy in northern Minnesota, a region 
rich in natural resources and related industrial enterprises.  Minnesota Power serves approximatel y 
150,000 customers , including 14 municipal systems and some of the nation’s largest  industrial 
customers, in a 26,000 -square -mile service territory  in northern Minnesota.8 As a business unit  of 
ALLETE, Minnesota Power is not a separate and distinct legal entity.   
ALLETE’s  regulated operations in addition to Minnesota Power include  Superior Water, 
Light & Power (“SWL &P”), an electric, water, and  gas utility in Wisconsin , and  approximately

B. The Partners   
1. CPP Investments  
CPP Investments is a professional investment management organization that manages the 
Canada Pension Plan Fund (“Fund”), representing funds not needed by the Canada Pension Plan 
(“CPP”) to pay benefits, in the best interests of the CPP’s more than 22 million participating 
contributors and beneficiaries across Canada.   CPP Investments’ purpose is to help provide a 
foundation upon which contributors and beneficia ries can build their financial security in 
retirement, with the long -term goal to contribute to the financial strength of the CPP by maximizing 
the Fund’s returns without undue risk of loss. CPP Investments is governed and managed 
independently of the CPP and at arm’s length from governments.  
As of March  31, 2024, CPP Investments managed assets totaling  C$632.3 billion.  In order 
to build diversified portfolios of assets, investments are made around the world in public equities, 
private equities, real estate, infrastructure, and fixed income. CPP Investments has built a 
significant investment portfolio in the U nited States , with C$267.6  billion  (~US$197.7  billion ) 
invested directly and indirectly in equity and fixed income in public and private companies across 
the U nited States  economy, including in real estate, infrastructure, and energy. These investments 
represented approximately 42  percent  of total assets as of March  31, 2024.  
As an institutional investor with a broad global portfolio, CPP Investments invests across 
the energy sector, focusing on the energy transition and considering sustainability -related factors 
to ma ke more informed decisions to deliver superior long -term investment outcomes. As part of 
that approach, CPP Investments has committed to achieve net zero emissions across all scopes by 
 
7 2050 , in both its portfolio and operations, and growing Green & Transit ion assets to at least 
C$130  billion by 2030.  CPP Investments also has deep expertise across utilities, midstream  energy 
companies , and energy generation and has strategically partnered with numerous companies across 
these sectors. For example, CPP Investm ents successfully partnered with Puget Sound Energy 
(“Puget”), the largest electric and gas utility in Washington state with over 1.2 million customers, 
via a take -private transaction in 2007. This partnership similarly allowed Puget to execute its long -
term growth strategy and  accelerate its decarbonization efforts.   
CPP Investments ’ decision to pursue the Acquisition aligns with its long -term investment 
strategy, which includes investments in both conventional and renewable energy assets globally. 
As a lo ng-term investor, CPP Investments will bring its sector expertise and long -term capital to 
support ALLETE’s strong management team and its commitment to advancing a sustainable, 
clean -energy future while delivering safe, reliable , and affordable energy ser vices to its customers. 
CPP Investments recognizes ALLETE’s focus on safety, integrity, community engagement, and 
employee development, along with the quality ALLETE management team. CPP Investments 
prides itself on its responsible investment approach, whi ch is centered on investing the Fund in 
contributors’ and beneficiaries’ best interests, and believes that the delivery of ALLETE’s 
Sustainability -in-Action strategy will generate substantial value both for ALLETE’s customers 
and CPP Investments’ contribut ors and beneficiaries.  
2. Global Infrastructure Partners  
GIP is  the trading name of Global Infrastructure Management, LLC, which was founded 
in 2006. GIP is  a leading infrastructure investor that specializes in investing in, owning, and /or 
operating some of t he largest and most complex assets across the energy, transport, digital 
infrastructure, and water and waste management sectors . GIP has approximately $11 5 billion in 
assets under management and its portfolio companies employ over approximately 116,000 people , 
 
8 in each case as of March  31, 2024 . GIP’s focus on real infrastructure assets, combined with its 
deep proprietary origination network and comprehensive  operational expertise, enables GIP to be 
responsible stewards of its investors’ capital and to create positive economic impact for 
communities. Additionally, with decarbonization central to its investment thesis, GIP is well 
positioned to support the glob al energy transition and aspires to be one of the world’s leading 
owners, developers, and operators of renewable energy assets. GIP capitalizes on its leadership in 
renewables, expertise in midstream and transport infrastructure, and strong relationships w ith 
business and government leaders to contribute efficiently to the world’s decarbonization.  
GIP’s decision to pursue the Acquisition is directly tied to ALLETE’s commitment to 
decarbonize its system while continuing to effectively serve its customers and  communities. 
Equally important is the high quality of ALLETE’s management team and employees, along with 
the Company’s established track record of delivering on its commitments to the energy transition 
and the customers and communities it serves. GIP has a long track record of investment in the 
utility sector.  
GIP’s practice is to invest in infrastructure assets using common investment fund s or 
similar investment structures that typically include three separate legal entities: the general partner, 
the lim ited partners, and the fund itself. This structure allows GIP to provide clear lines of 
ownership and control of the assets in which each fund invests. The fund’s general partner typically 
has legal authority and control over the actions of the fund and ha s the responsibility to manage 
the fund according to governance documents and certain fiduciary duties . The limited partner(s) 
of a fund are the entities (primarily) or individuals that invest their capital in the fund; they receive 
very limited rights related to major decisions  impacting the fund  (such as liquidation of the fund), 
but do not have the ability to participate in the day -to-day decisions of such fund  or make 
 
9 investment decisions on behalf of the fund . Likewise, i t is common for firms like GIP to use an 
investment structure that includes intermediate companies that may allow for variation in liability, 
taxation, and other important corporate characteristics that are independent of any particular 
investment or acquisition.  
Earlier this year, GIP  announced a transaction whereby BlackRock will acquire 100  percent  
of the limited liability company interests of GIP (the “GIP/BlackRock Transaction”). After 
completion of this transaction, BlackRock will have an indirect interest in the  ultimate general 
partner entities that control each of the  GIP funds, but GIP will continue to be the fund manager. 
The strategic and day -to-day operations and activities of GIP, including  the funds that are investing 
in ALLETE, will continue to be managed as they are now.  The current GIP management team will 
continue to manage the key strategic direction, operations and activities of the business (including 
decisions in respect of the GIP funds). The GIP/BlackRock Transaction is currently awaiting the 
last required regulat ory approvals, and is anticipated to close in the third quarter of 2024.

III. PURPOSE AND  BENEFITS OF THE ACQUISITION  
A. Standard of Review  
Minnesota Power  is making this filing consistent with  the provisions of  Minn. Stat. 
§ 216B.50 , Minn. R. 7825.1800, and Minn. R. 7825.1700.  Minn. Stat. § 216B.50  requires 
Commission approval before any public utility may  “sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an 
operating unit or system in this state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000, or merge or 
consolidate with another public utility or transmission company operating in this state .”  
Under Minnesota law, the Commission must  find that the  Acquisition  is “consistent with 
the public interest .”18 In previous decisions, the Commission has  determined that this standard 
does not  require an affirmative finding of  public benefit  but requires only a finding that  the 
transaction is compatible with  the public interest.19 Similarly, the Commission has stated that  
 
17 A copy of the July 3, 2024 Moody’s Ratings Credit Opinion for ALLETE is attached as Attachment  J-1. Moody’s 
expects the Acquisition to have a neutral to positive impact on AL LETE’s credit rating.  A copy of the May 7, 2024 
S&P Global Ratings Credit Opinion for ALLETE is attached as Attachment J -2; at the time of the announcement, 
S&P revised its outlook from stable to negative based on the possibility of higher leverage but aff irmed all ratings.  
18 Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  
19 See In the Matter of the Proposed Merger of Minnegasco, Inc. with and into. Arkla, Inc. , Docket No. G -008/PA -
90-604, ORDER APPROVING MERGER  AND ADOPTING AMENDED STIPULATION WITH 
MODIFICATIONS at 4 (Nov. 27 , 1990).  
 
13 Minn. Stat. §  216B.50  “does not require that proposed mergers  affirmatively benefit ratepayers or 
the public or that they othe rwise promote the public interest. ”20 Rather, the  Acquisition  “cannot 
contravene the public interest  . . . and must be shown to be compatible with it. ”21 Under this 
standard, the  “perceived detriments  or concerns must be weighed against perceived benefits to the 
public.  If the perceived detriments do not outweigh the perceived  benefits, the  merger is deemed 
to be  ‘consistent with the public interest. ’”22 
B. Application of the Standard of Review  
The Acquisition  is consistent with the public interest  and readily meets the  Commission ’s 
corresponding public interest  standard . As discussed, there will be no  adverse impact on 
customers , service cost or quality , employees , or communities.  The Partners are not seeking to 
make changes to the operation of the Minn esota Power utility or the regulatory construct in 
Minnesota.  Nor is this a transaction about cutting costs or fundamentally changing cost structures 
or long -term plans for the Minnesota Power utility; rather, it is about finding a better way to support 
the Company’s ongoing sustainability efforts and achievement of State policy goals.   
In fact, t he Acquisition  will produce significant benefits by  allowing ALLETE  to partner 
with global  leaders in the infrastructure space who share its vision and are aligned with its values,  
and who intend to provide the Company with the capital necessary to continue leading  the State 
of Minnesota in transitioning to a cleaner energy future while maintain ing the  reliable , safe and 
affordable  service on which  its Minnesota customers depend.

14 1. The Commission’s Authority Will Be Unchanged by the Acquisition.  
The Acquisition will not change the role or diminish the existing regulatory authority of 
the Commission.  Regulation of Minnesota Power’s rates and costs will remain the same and in 
alignment with the regulatory construct in Minnesota and long -standing Commission approaches.  
At the same time, Minnesota Power retains its obligation to provide safe, reliable, and affordable 
service to its customers.  Ultimately, the Minnesota Power utility is wholly unchanged in terms of 
its customer profile, system load, employee obligations, utility infrastructure and system needs, 
level of financing needs, and align ment with State policy goals.  These are all aspects of Minnesota 
Power that are known to the Commission from a regulatory perspective, and will remain the subject 
of many current, ongoing, and upcoming dockets before the Commission where they will continue  
to be evaluated in the same manner after the Acquisition.  
2. ALLETE Applied Rigorous Due Diligence .  
This Acquisition and partnership were not chosen lightly.  Rather, ALLETE has solicited 
and agreed to the Acquisition to advance its current strategy and goa ls, and has identified partners 
that share its vision, commitment to clean energy, and support for the Company’s customers, 
communities , and quality of service.   
As demonstrated by the details set forth in the Definitive  Proxy  Statement attached to this 
Petition, the Company went to great lengths to fully explore potential partnerships while also 
working diligently to ensure the Partners that were selected align with the Company’s goals . This 
diligence resulted in a partnership with infrastructure -savvy inv estors who are familiar with the 
energy industry and align with Minnesota Power’s values that have served customers effectively 
for generations.  There is no guarantee any other partnership would be as productive for all parties 
involved, or ultimately better serve customers.  
 
15 The Acquisition  is also subject to several additional  utility  regulatory approvals  as 
previously noted , including the PSCW  and FERC  approvals, for which applications are being 
submitted simultaneously or near in time to this Petition filing.  Minnesota Power  agree s to notify 
the Commission regarding the outcome of those proceedings  through filings in the Commission’s 
eDockets system, a nd to keep the Commission reasonably informed about developments in these 
proceedings.  
This Petition (including Attachments) contains extensive information regarding the 
Acquisition, including further addressing the requirements of Minnesota Statutes and Rules with 
respect to the information required for such transactions in Section IV of the Petition and in 
Attachments B -F, I, K -2, and L.  
3. The Reasons for the Acquisition are Sound.  
The energy industry is evolving rapidly  with the transition to more renewab le sources of 
energy,  as well as transmission and distribution  grid modernization, all while customer needs and 
preferences driv e change.  Throughout  Minnesota Power’s long history,  the Company  has 
successfully navigated  significant change by prioritizing innovation and creative approaches to the 
rapidly evolving world around  it while never losing focus on the unique customers and 
communities it serves . However, as previously noted, as of March 2024 , ALLETE  is the largest 
investor in renewable  energy , relative to market capitalization , of all publicly traded utilities in the 
United States .23 In concert with Minnesota’s decarbonization requirements,  ALLETE  will need to 
make substantial investments in renewable energy, carbon -reduction, grid resi liency and 
reliability, and clean -energy enabling technologies in the years ahead  at the Minnesota Power 
utility and  all of the ALLETE companies.  After extensive consideration, t he Company  has 
 
23 2023 Annual Report , https://www.allete.com/Content/Documents/Investors/AnnualReports/2023AR.pdf .  
 
16 concluded that partnering with highly experienced  owners who sh are its values and can dedicate 
resources to the Company and its Sustainability in Action strategy  is the best path forward for the 
Company and its  customers, communities , and employees.   
The Company also determined that as a relatively small energy compan y with significant 
needs for access to capital, transitioning away from the risk of volatility associated with seeking 
financing in public markets is in the best interests of all stakeholders.  The Company further 
determined that the Partners can provide bo th a solid financial underpinning and industry expertise 
that will better support the Company’s infrastructure investment strategies and goals. Like other 
investors, private infrastructure investors such as the Partners seek a reasonable return on their 
investments and a reasonable opportunity to earn that return .24 But private investors such as the 
Partners have an ability to exercise  more patience with respect to quarterly earnings and dividends  
due to a  focus on long -term investment s. In another example , well -financed private investors can 
provide more readily available  capital than can be accessed reliably  in the public markets .  
To these ends, the Company made its own choice to seek out private infrastructure 
investors, particularly those with e xpertise in the energy industry, and chose CPP Investments and 
GIP specifically.  The Partners are highly regarded infrastructure investors with deep industry 
expertise, resources, and strong long -term outlooks.  Together, they bring decades of experience 
investing in large -scale infrastructure businesses across sectors to support sustainable, long -term 
growth.   
 
24 One question that has come up in discussions with Minnesota Power stakeholders is how the Commission would 
determine the cost of capital for a privately owned utility company.  The methodology for determining the cost of 
capital, or equity specifically, for a regulated utility company does not change based on public versus private 
ownership, because both scenarios  continue to involve comparisons to proxy groups and models based on those proxy 
groups.  Further, ALLETE will still  have a credit rating and be subject to credit rating agency reports  that provide 
transparency and insight into the financial health of the utility.   
 
17 In alignment with these views, t he Partners became involved in the Acquisition for reasons 
that correspond to many of the benefits recognized by ALLE TE. Both Partners pride themselves 
on their responsible investment approach es, which are centered on delivering long -term value to 
their organizations and the communities in which they operate.  The Partners have  successful track 
records of long -term partne rships with infrastructure businesses, and recognize the importance of 
ALLETE and Minnesota Power to their employees and to the communities they serve and in which 
they operate. Their  interest in ALLETE is likewise long term and is not predicated on any changes 
to ALLETE or any changes to ALLETE’s operational practices. Retaining and supporting 
ALLETE’s current management team and employees, along with ALLETE’s commitment to 
supporting low income and disadvantaged pa rts of the communities ALLETE serves, is critical to 
the Partners’  commitment to the Acquisition.  
The Partners also share the Company’s  values of safety, integrity, planet , and people.  As 
demonstrated by the extensive commitments set forth in the Merger Ag reement, the Partners 
recognize the importance of Company employees and the Company’s  ties to the communities it 
serves  and in which it operates . The Partners share the Company’s support for a collaborative 
stakeholder approach which will continue going fo rward.  They further share the Company’s view 
that customers are at the center of its business, and that serving customers and meeting their needs 
is paramount – consistent with the Company’s long utility history.   
4. Commitments to Minne sota 
The Company and t he Partners  have made several  contractual commitments and 
agreements  in the Merger Agreement , attached as Attachment B to the Petition.  Overall, the 
commitments highlighted below underscore ALLETE’s and the Partners’ dedication to supporting 
employees, customers, and communities, meeting State policy goals, and providing safe, reliable, 
and reasonably priced electric service to customers.  In addition, the Company and the Partners 
 
18 look forward to learning about other matters of importance to st akeholders  as this proceeding 
moves forward . 
Headquarters:  ALLETE will continue to maintain the  headquarters of Minnesota Power 
in Duluth, Minnesota . 
Names:  The name of ALLETE will be “ALLETE .” ALLETE will keep the current name 
of Minnesota Power as “Minnesota Power.”  
Company Employees:  For the two -year period following the Acquisition, each ALLETE 
nonunion employee who continues employment with ALLETE as of the effective time of the 
Acquisition will retain extensive protections, including the same or  better employment position in 
the same location , and wages, incentive, benefits, and employee protections no less favorable than 
those available to th e employee immediately prior to the Acquisition . These employees are also 
provided with other customary e mployee protections, such as recognition of pre -acquisition 
service with ALLETE for benefit plan purposes, waiver of pre -existing condition limitations under 
post-acquisition health plans , and credit for deductibles and co -payments under post -closing plans  
for the year of the Acquisition.  
ALLETE will also continue to honor its union contracts.  This includes terms of 
compensation, benefits, and work conditions among other portions of any applicable union 
contract.  ALLETE will satisfy all notice, information, consultation, bargaining or consent 
obligations owed to any labor union, labor organization or employee representative of any union 
employee in connection with the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition.   
Additionally, neither the Company nor its Partners intend to change the Company’s long -
standing practices with regard to contractors.  For example, the Company routinely contractually 
requires contractors and subcontractors to pay their workers the prevaili ng wage as evidenced by 
 
19 local collective bargaining agreements, and to ascertain local conditions, work rules, and union 
jurisdiction.  The Company also seeks to deploy union labor wherever reasonably possible.  
Maintaining Current Management:  The Company will maintain the current senior 
management team, subject to changes to account for voluntary departures or terminations in the 
ordinary course . The Company and the Partners expect that the current ALLETE management 
team (including the managing team of the M innesota Power utility) will continue to operate the 
utility in the normal course, consistent with current management functions.  Further, the decision -
making specific to the Minnesota Power utility will remain with local management, subject to the 
oversigh t of the Board of Directors (just as local management reports to its Board of Directors 
now).  
Local/Independent Directors:  At least one member of the ALLETE Board of Directors 
will be from Minnesota  and one from Wisconsin, and two members of the ALLETE Board of 
Directors  will be independent directors.  The chief executive officer of ALLETE , currently Bethany 
Owen,25 will be a member of the Board of Directors .  
Budgets:  Consistent with current Board of Directors  roles and obligations, c apital budgets, 
includi ng material variances of such budgets  for the Company as a whole , will be approved by a 
majority of the Board of Directors  of ALLETE . 
Community Commitments:  After the Closing , ALLETE will maintain certain historic 
levels of economic development and charitable contributions in service territories of ALLETE and 
ALLETE subsidiaries , including Minnesota Power and the State of Minnesota . These levels are 
set forth in Attachment G . 
 
25 See prior commitment with respect to retention of current management.  
 
20 Separateness : The Commission is familiar with the affiliated interest agreements and 
arrangements within the ALLETE family of companies that protect the Minnesota Power customer 
and provide appropriate governance for the entities under the ALLETE umbrella.  Except for 
updating the tax -sharing agreement to include the Parent, the Acquisition will not cause a change 
to those affiliate relationships.  With respect to ALLETE and the parent entities up through the 
Partners, ALLETE will maintain certain corporate separateness (i.e., “ring -fencing”) commitments 
with respect to Parent and other upstream entities, including:26  
• ALLETE and Parent will maintain separate books and records, agree to prohibitions 
against loans or pledges of assets of ALLETE without regulatory approval, and 
generally hold ALLETE harmless from any business and financial risk exposures 
associated with Parent or its subsidiaries or affiliates  (other than any subsidiary of 
ALLETE) ; 
• ALLETE and Parent will provide regulators with appropriate access to ALLETE’s 
books and records; appropriate access to ALLETE’s financial information and filings; 
access to and audit rights with respect to the documents supporting Parent’s costs that 
may be allocable to ALLETE; and appropriate access to ALLETE’s board minutes, 
audit  reports, and information provided to or by credit rating agencies pertaining to 
ALLETE;  
• ALLETE and Parent will maintain separate debt and stock, if any;  
• Neither ALLETE nor Parent shall provide direct credit support to a credit facility of 
the other throug h a guarantee, and none of ALLETE’s credit facilities shall include any 
cross -default provision whereby a default under any of Parent’s credit facilities would 
cause a default under any of ALLETE’s credit facilities;  
• ALLETE will maintain its own corporate and debt credit rating, and its own ratings for 
long-term debt;  
• ALLETE will not make or declare a distribution, unless on the date of such distribution 
ALLETE’s corporate credit/issuer rating is at least investment grade (or its then 
equivalent) with S&P, Moody’s , or Fitch Ratings, unless ALLETE first files with and 
receives authorization from the applicable regulator for such distribution;  
 
26 These conditions do not preclude  the Company from  request ing to a governmental entity that they be limited to a 
portion of ALLETE , or to certain of its subsidiaries  or affiliates.  However, these commitments also do not change the 
current structure of ALLETE or its family of entities, including currently existing affiliated interest agreements and 
separations between regulated and non -regulated entities.  
 
21 • Parent may pledge its ownership of ALLETE for the benefit of Parent’s lenders unless 
prohibited by the applicable regu latory authority, but may not pledge the assets of 
ALLETE unless specifically allowed by the applicable regulatory authority;  
• ALLETE will not transfer any asset or facility of ALLETE to Parent or any subsidiary 
or affiliate of Parent (excluding any ALLETE subsidiary) without first obtaining 
authorization from the applicable regulatory authority, except for those transfers that 
do not require regulatory approval under applicable laws;  
• ALLETE will be structured such that, in the event of a bankruptcy of Paren t or any of 
its subsidiaries or affiliates (other than ALLETE and its subsidiaries), a bankruptcy 
court will not consolidate the assets and liabilities of ALLETE with Parent or any 
Parent entity, and, except as may be required by law, any costs incurred as  a result of 
bankruptcy of Parent or any Parent entity cannot be sought from ALLETE; and  
• Parent officers and directors that are employed by entities in the direct organizational 
structure between ALLETE and the Parents shall not be permitted to hold senior  
management positions with ALLETE.  
No Acquisition Premium:  Minnesota Power  will not attempt to recover the acquisition 
premium of the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition  from its utility customers.  
Transaction Costs:  Minnesota Power  will not attempt to recover from its utility customers  
the costs of executing the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition.  This includes, among 
other things, legal fees, goodwill, regulatory filing costs, and other costs historically recognized as 
transaction costs.  Minnesota Power and the Partners will likewise not deploy “push down 
accounting” (i.e., adjustment of Minnesota Power’s asset or liability values or books and records 
to reflect the purchase price) with respect to the Acqui sition.27 
 
27 Minnesota Power maintains its books in accordance with the Uniform System of Accounts and does not intend to 
adjust the hi storical cost values of its assets and liabilities, record any goodwill, nor include costs in its cost of service 
that are related to the Acquisition.  In accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles in the United States, 
Parent  will account for  the transaction using the acquisition (or purchase) method of accounting for business 
combinations.  The related purchase accounting journal entries, including the creation of goodwill, will be recorded at 
Parent and will not be pushed down to Minnesota Po wer, resulting in no changes to Minnesota Power’s books related 
to the purchase accounting journal entries. Transaction -related costs incurred by ALLETE will be recorded in Account 
426.5, Other Deductions and not included in Minnesota Power’s cost of servi ce.  
 
 
22 Transition Costs:  Minnesota Power  will not attempt to recover transition costs, if any, of 
the transactions contemplated by the Acquisition from its utility customers, except to the extent 
the transition costs produce savings (and then only when and if  such savings materialize).  
Debt Maintenance:  Minnesota Power will use commercially reasonable efforts to 
maintain its debt/equity ratios and its corporate and facility ratings in accordance with regulatory 
requirements.  
Affordability Programs and Ac cess:  Minnesota Power commits that it will not reduce 
the overall scope or resources dedicated to its affordability programs, nor current processes for 
residential customer access to affordability programs following the completion of the Acquisition.  
Minne sota Power acknowledges the Commission has authority to approve, reject, or modify any 
changes to affordability programs that the Company may propose  and that the Company must file 
all rate schedules with the Commission under Minn. Stat. Ch. 216B . As such,  this commitment  is 
intended to provide additional assurance without limiting or changing either the Company’s 
ongoing commitment to supporting low -income customers or the Commission’s role in approving 
such programs.   
Books and Records /Reporting Transpare ncy: Minnesota Power will continue to provide 
the Commission access to Minnesota Power ’s books, records, and information. In addition, the 
Company has compiled a comparison of SEC and other investor -related reporting that ALLETE 
currently undertakes to the  comparable information that will be available to regulators after the 
Acquisition . This comparison  is attached to the Petition as Attachment  H. As this comparison  
illustrates, the potentially relevant information available to the Commission post -Acquisition will 
be substantially similar to what is available now – just in slightly different f orms.  Further, 
Minnesota Power will continue to make all required annual filings with the Commission, including 
 
23 but not limited to annual capital structure filings and Jurisdictional Annual Reports that provide

information in these filings as required by Commission order, including its current obligation to 
provide credit rating agency  reports.  Though not required by Commission Order, ALLETE will 
continue to publish its Corporate Sustainability Report, which contains information related to 
environmental, social , and governance issues, including the Company’s efforts to encourage  
diversi ty, equity , and inclusion efforts.  
C. Process to Evaluate Public Interest  
Minnesota Power understands  that the Commission will want to undertake a  robust process 
of evaluating the proposed transaction with the input of interested  stakeholders, will require 
sufficient time to do so, and that no potential change in  ownership can occur without the 
Commission’s approval . As discussed at the Commission planning meeting on May 9, 2024, 
referral of the matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings (“OAH ”) offers the benefits of a 
robust, defined, and efficient process for intervention and public comment, for clear positions from 
the parties, and for the collection of evidence and the recommendation of an Administrative Law 
Judge (“ALJ”)  that may be helpful to the Commission.  Minnesota Power supports referral to the 
OAH if the Commission prefers  and would anticipate providing Direct Testimony consistent with 
other case processes.  Minnesota Power  also believes it is within the  Commission’s discretion to 
determ ine whether to assess  the Acquisition  through notice and comment processes . Minnesota 
Power will of course participate  in any process and work to provide all necessary information as 
transparently, promptly,  and efficiently as possible.   
 
24 Because t his Petit ion is made in accordance with  Minn. Stat. §  216B.50 ,28 no statutorily 
imposed  time frame for a Commission decision  applies . While the Company has indicated a desire 
to close the transaction, should it be approved, by mid -2025, the Company and Partners hav e 
committed, and continue to commit, to providing the Commission with the time it requires to 
evaluate the Petition and the Acquisition itself.  Within this context, Minnesota Power  requests that 
the Commission balance these considerations in establishing a  procedural plan for this proceeding . 
To this end, Minnesota Power submits for Commission consideration  the following key 
procedural dates for an ALJ -directed case process .   
Milestone/Event  Target Date  
Petition for Approval  July 19, 2024  
Commission Referral to OAH  early August  2024  
Public Hearings  October/November 2024  
Evidentiary Hearings  December 17-19, 2024  
ALJ Report  March 12, 2025  
Commission Agenda Meeting  early May 2025  
Commission Order  June 16, 2025

path for evaluation of the Petition  and a schedule for doing so .

In this section of the Petition, Minnesota Power seeks to provide additional information

This Acquisition is a transfer subject to the filing requirements of Minn. Stat. §  216B.50, 
and therefore in turn Min n. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800(B), (C), and (D),30 as well as other Rules 
cross -referenced therein.   
Minn. R. 782 5.1700 requires that:  
A public utility, prior to entering into a transaction, shall petition for and receive 
from the commission by formal written order approval for such transaction. A 
petition for approval of capital structure (parts  7825.1000  to 7825.1500 ) shall be 
filed concurrently with the petition for approval of transfer, merger, or 
consolidation if consideration for such a transaction is a security or s ecurities as 
defined in part  7825.1000 . The commission may require an independent valuation 
of the property involved in the transaction.  
 
The Company is submitting  this Petition as its request for formal written approval.  The additional 
requirements of  Minn. R. 7825.1700 and the Rules cross -referenced therein are addressed in 
Section IV.C  below.
